title: family feud erupts asda car
story: Family feud erupts in Asda car park as man bites sisters ex-boyfriends earAnthony Douglas, , jumped into a car with his dad James Snow and went looking for Ryan Arnold before viciously attacking him, Liverpool Crown Court heard todayAnthony Douglas outside Liverpool Crown Court Image: Liverpool EchoByNeil Docking:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA man left his sister’s ex-boyfriend in need of stitches to his ear after sinking his teeth into him when a family feud erupted in a supermarket carpark.Anthony Douglas, , jumped into a car with his dad James Snow and went looking for Ryan Arnold before viciously attacking him, Liverpool Crown Court heard today, Liverpool Echo reports. Douglas heard from his girlfriend, Sophie McCormick, who worked at Asda Huyton, that Mr Arnold was at the supermarket branch and went after him, prompted by the victim’s acrimonious break-up with Douglas’ sister, Marie. CCTV cameras captured what followed, as he bit Mr Arnold in the exact place the victim had previously suffered another bite. David Watson, prosecuting, said Mr Arnold and Miss Douglas had a five-year-old child together. However, by February , , when the brawl occurred, they had been separated in what was apparently an acrimonious split for around six to eight months.  Mr Watson said Mr Arnold had started a new relationship with a woman called Fay Murray, with whom he had fathered twins. The twins were reportedly ill at the time. Mr Arnold and Miss Murray went to the Asda store at around .pm, when the latter went into the shop and Mr Arnold remained in his Ford Galaxy in a bid to avoid the defendantaposs girlfriend Sophie McCormick, who he knew worked there. Evidently, Sophie McCormick on seeing Faye Murray did contact the defendant,” the prosecutor said. Douglas subsequently turned up at the store with his dad around .pm, at which time he was seen running into the supermarket and saying where is he  before he approached Mr Arnold and shouted: Alright Ryan. Mr Watson said the victim was concerned his car would be damaged so got out, with the engine still running, but Douglas jumped into the driveraposs seat and drove the Ford around the car park. He said: Ryan Arnoldaposs next recollection is the defendant and James Snow standing directly in front of him, calling him a aposgrassapos and a aposratapos. The defendant, who can be seen to be in a highly animated, agitated state throughout on the CCTV footage, is seen to lean into Ryan Arnold, who describes himself being bitten to the left ear. Miss Murray rang the police and Mr Arnold described himself as being frightened and confused and in a lot of pain and distress. He went to Whiston Hospital, where he was treated for two cm bite marks to either side of his left ear, which required stitches. Mr Watson said the bite was in the same place as a signicant bite injury, which he suffered around  years earlier. He said the victim needed a tetanus booster and three months later still had pain in his ear, already disfigured by the previous bite. Douglas was arrested at home on February  and denied the attack, but ahead of a trial in September admitted wounding. Mr Watson said Mr Arnold was now back in a relationship with Miss Douglas. Douglas, of Mardale Road, Huyton, has four previous convictions for six offences, including dishonesty. He was fined in October  after threatening to damage his mumaposs windows. Desmond Lennon, defending, said his client accepted his guilt, despite claims made in a pre-sentence report, and was “sorry and ashamed” for what he had done.The barrister said Douglas, who has cystic fibrosis, diabetes and arthritis, endured a very dficult childhood. However, he had been in a stable relationship with his girlfriend, the barrister said, for five years and hoped to start a family with her.Mr Lennon said Douglas had responsibility for a -year-old sister, who lives with him and his partner and is at college. Both she and his girlfriend would sufferhe was jailed, he said. Douglas had stopped drinking and smoking cannabis, the lawyer said, and was behaving in a “more restrained” way. Mr Lennon pointed out that rehabilitation was more likely for Douglashe addressed the root cause of his offending. Judge Woodhall said Douglas was unfit to work, his partner was his full time carer and accepted he had dficulties in childhood. For whatever reason, the judge said, there was history between Douglas and Mr Arnold, following his victimaposs acrimonious split with his sister. The judge said: You were contacted and told, I have no doubt, there had been either a confrontation inside [Asda] or that his partner was inside, and therefore you wanted to intervene. As you describe it yourself, you had seen red, you were pumped up, you were angry, you were agitated. The judge said Douglas got in Mr Arnoldaposs car and drove it around to wind him up, before confronting him. The CCTV footage shows youaposre highly animated and agitated, unlike your victim,” he said. You walked up to him, pulled his head in towards you and bit his ear. Judge Woodhall said: Your sister and Mr Arnold are now reconciled. That causes some concern because it means Mr Arnold is still in the family. The judge said he had to sentence Douglas in a way to best manage future risk and agreed Douglas had a realistic prospect of rehabilitation. He therefore handed him  weeks - around  months - in prison, suspended for  months. The judge also imposed a six-month home curfew, between pm and am daily, a -day Rehabilitation Activity Requirement and £ court costs. that their homes are becoming surrounded by rubbish claiming some tower block tenants are throwing dirty nappies from their windows. Flats in Chelmsley Wood, Birmingham, are reportedly becoming targeted by fly-tippers who also leave piles of junk and furniture on street corners. Landlord Solihull Community Housing said aerial fly-tipping had become a frequent issue at the flats and vowed to take action against those responsible.Residents in neighbouring flat Oriel House, a short distance away, had received a warning after items - including “bags of excrement” - were thrown from windows, reports Birmingham Live.Tenants received a letter from Solihull Council about the environmental crime after some inappropriately disposed of their mess.  BirminghamLive visited several tower blocks in the Solihull area on October , all of which were clean and tidy with the exception of Bangor House. Emil Kerekes, a neighbour of the flat, which houses mostly council tenants, said the mess was a daily occurrence.The -year-old pastor runs the nearby Connection Church Centre with its own community cafe.He said he had witnessed residents throwing dirty nappies out of the window and told how he was verbally abused when he challenged them.  Emil said: Iaposve seen people from the top floors throwing nappies out of the windows. I tried to tell them it wasnapost nice and they swore at me. He said it was important the area was clean and tidy to help the well-being of the community. Itaposs not good for business, itaposs not good for the environment, itaposs not good for anybody, he said.  I think itaposs down to education. People need to see that what they are doing is wrong. Emile added that while it was due to the selfish actions of a small number of residents, he had seen problems with rubbish persist for at least three years. I donapost think itaposs a big number. Itaposs just a couple of people. I think most people are responsible, he added. But it happens regularly, thataposs the problem. Itaposs not like it has just happened once, it is every week.  Fiona Hughes, chief executive at Solihull Community Housing, said: “We have a team of estate assistants who work hard to maintain a good standard around our high-rise buildings. Unfortunately, there are some residents who choose to throw their rubbish out of the window rather than using the bin chutes provided. This behaviour is completely unacceptable and we will take action against any resident found to be doing this as they are breaking the terms of their tenancy agreement. Aerial fly-tipping has become a frequent issue around Bangor House and we are currently exploring new initiatives to help tackle the problem. A multi-agency approach has been introduced to support the maintenance of the area and help us identy those who are responsible. We encourage residents to share any information they have with us and report incidents of fly-tipping as soon as possible”. news uk-news inside-creepy-fairground-graveyard-popular-"Cleethorpes: Inside abandoned theme park before demolitionByRuby PensonKirsty CardTim Hanlon:,  Oct | commentsA once packed fairground is now a creepy graveyard attracting urban explorers despite the dangers.Pleasure Island in Cleethorpes, North East Lincolnshire, opened in May  and was a draw for local families and tourists until it closed at the end of the  season. It is now a shadow of its former self, as these eerie photos from the Abandoned UK Facebook page show boarded-up structures that used to house dodgems and other rides have started to fall apart, reported the Daily Star. There are many hidden dangers but that has not deterred explorers from creeping onto the site. It has become the second-highest visited destination by them, and they trespass on the expansive site risking their lives, according to Grimsby Live. The sign for the Dodgems hangs high next to Kiddiesapos Cove. Nearby you can almost still hear the screams from the Razzle Dazzle, Ala Kazam, The Obliterator and The Pendulus. Ali Babaaposs Arcade still stands but is empty. Some reports claim that the last of the items were sold off in October , as the carousel sold for a six-figure sum over two years ago just before going up for auction. Vast amounts of material which has been recycled. Cleethorpes Light Railway have the track from the site. The go-kart track is massively overgrown. There is also evidence of fires started deliberately which is a sad legacy for a previously joyful place. Reports say bulldozers were meant to be hitting the site in June to make way for a Lidl store and a vast -eco lodge holiday centre. Plans also include a hotel and conference centre and food hall. Abandoned UK posted the eerie images from their exploration of the site in . Fans reminiscing over their time at the popular family attraction were sad to have seen it disappear.  One commenter said: Sad to see it like this, I remember when it first opened then, later on, worked there in . As most would say it wasn’t the best of theme parks but the kids loved it and made a great day out for them, had some good memories there. Another wrote: Always makes me sad to see abandoned theme parks after it made so many good memories. Camelot looks sorry for itself and I loved it there. Still, the spookier the better. A third added: This one makes me feel a little sad, being local to it I spent many a fun day with my mates there in the summer holidays and then with my own children. Such a shame it was left to go the way it did when it had so much potential to get even better. title: inside eerie travellers camp dale
story: Inside eerie Travellers camp Dale Farm  years after it was abandoned and left to rotIn , Dale Farm in Essex was the scene of one of Britains largest and most violent evictions. Now, properties in the area are decaying, overgrown by shrubs and trees.Properties on Dale Farm in Essex are decaying Image: Spartacus   SplashNewsByChiara Fiorillo:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsPictures have emerged from an eerie Travellers camp that was abandoned and left to rot  years ago. In , Dale Farm in Essex was the scene of one of Britainaposs largest and most violent evictions. The Travellers community who lived there was evicted by Basildon Council because it wanted to build new housing on the land. However, new photos show that the construction of new buildings never started, and instead the properties that people once called home are decaying, overgrown by shrubs and trees. Marble flooring is still visible, as well as charred remains from the fires that raged the site and electricity points are still attached to walls.  Even a police public order fire extinguisher could be seen amongst the rubble, an image shows. Among other things, childrenaposs toys and garden tools were left in the area and were never removed. Travellers living nearby have spoken out  years after the evictions, saying they were asked to leave as the council wanted to build new housing, but this never happened. Dale Farm was once the largest illegal Travellers site in Europe, with , people living there at one point.  The evictions at the camp in Crays Hill, Essex, took a long time and were delayed multiple times in  after a decade-long planning row.Once, they were delayed due to fears bats could have made the land their home.At the time, we reported that the High Court postponed the eviction three times. When police moved in to clear the site in October ,  officers and six residents were injured, with  protesters arrested.  It is estimated the evictions cost nearly £million in taxpayersapos money. Basildon Council were hit with a bill for £.m while Essex Police spent £.m on their involvement.Mary Sheridan, a woman who lived at Dale Farm for eight years and was among those evicted in , ed to the site two years later and told Socialist Worker : I was happy living here.But look at how we have to live now. We’re living in filth. Another Traveller, Martin OaposLeary, said the area he used to live on had become a pothole, a swimming pool for rats.Now, it is believed that around  Travellers live on a permanent Traveller site neighbouring the Dale Farm land, according to Basildon Echo News.However, the community is reportedly fed up of Basildon and wants to move away from south Essex. The Mirror has contacted Basildon Council for comment. title: its both exciting soothing wild
story: It’s both exciting and soothing - the wild new hobby one woman swears byAs KFC launches its limited edition Zinger Popcorn Bucket, we celebrate the thrill of trying something newWould you try lake swimming AdvertorialByEimear OHagan:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct If we’ve learnt anything over the past year and a half, it’s that you never know what’s around the corner, so itaposs important to seize opportunities, push ourselves out of our comfort zone and live for the moment. KFC is doing just that by encouraging people to spice things up to mark the launch of its tasty new Zinger Popcorn Bucket - available for a limited time only. So to join in the fun, weaposre championing people who have challenged themselves to try new things, including Jenny Holden who has ed head first into wild swimming. The forty-seven-year-old mum of ten-year-old twins from Lichfield, Staffordshire, explains that she was in search of a new challenge, and one that would bring some excitement to her le.  ‘With my children a bit older, and less dependent on me, I found myself with a little bit more time for myself, and I wanted to use it doing something fun,’ says Jenny who runs her own PR company Chorus Communications. ‘Especially post lockdowns, with so much time spent at home, being sedentary and growing bored of my normal activities, I was craving a new hobby, and one that would really exhilarate me.’ A friend suggested Jenny try wild swimming at a quarry near her home and Jenny decided to give it a go, albeit with some nerves. ‘I’m a keen swimmer but the idea of swimming in that sort of environment was completely new to me. Also, wouldn’t it be freezing  I was intrigued enough to give it a go though, and took my first dip in August with one of my sons. ‘Plunging into the water, my first thought was – wow it’s cold! But actually, once you become acclimatised to the water temperature it feels wonderful. That first swim was really memorable, I came out of the water feeling revived and invigorated, and I knew I was a convert.’ Jenny persuaded three friends to form a wild swim gang with her and since August they have met weekly for a dip. ‘I don’t wear a wetsuit, it’s too much faff getting in and out of one, just a swimsuit and now I look forward to my swim all week. ‘Front crawling through open water, surrounded by the sounds and sights nature, it’s so amazing and it washes away the stresses of the week. It’s nothing like swimming in a pool, it’s both exciting and soothing, brilliant for body and mind. ‘It’s definitely going to get a bit nippier as we go into winter but I’m ready for the challenge!’ So in the spirit of taking the plunge and trying something new, e into a Zinger Popcorn Bucket soon - it is only around for a limited period, available until October .Download the app, head in store or order online. news uk-news kate-middleton-wows-red-arrives-"Kate Middleton arrives at the Forward Trust campaign eventByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsThe Duchess of Cambridge was the lady in red as she joined Ant and Dec at an addiction awareness event.Kate delivered a keynote speech at the event, which was hosted by the TV duo and the Forward Trust to launch the charityaposs Taking Action on Addiction campaign.For the event at the BAFTA headquarters on Londonaposs Piccadilly, Kate sported a long red pleated skirt with a matching red polo neck top. She teamed it with tan heels and a matching bag.And in her speech, she called for compassion and empathy for those who are struggling with addiction.She said: Addiction is not a choice. No one chooses to become an addict. But it can happen to any one of us. None of us are immune. Yet it’s all too rarely discussed as a serious mental health condition. And seldom do we take the time to uncover and fully understand its fundamental root causes.The journey towards addiction is often multi-layered and complex. But, by recognising what lies beneath addiction, we can help remove the taboo and shame that sadly surrounds it.As a society, we need to start from a position of compassion and empathy. Where we nurture those around us, understand their journey, and what has come before them.We need to value and prioritise care and support, helping to restore and connect iniduals who are clearly suffering, to the people around them. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up . That is why I am so passionate about the work of The Forward Trust, an organisation I am so proud to be patron of. This is the work that you, and many other charities, provide day in, day out. And it is needed now, more than ever.Kate also talked about the effect of the pandemic and how the number of those struggling with addiction is higher than ever before.  She added: The pandemic has had a devastating impact on addiction rates. And families and children are having to cope with addiction in greater numbers than ever before.We know that over one and a half million people across the UK who did not have substance misuse prior to lockdown, may now be experiencing problems associated with increased alcohol consumption.Around two million iniduals who were identied as being in recovery, may have experienced a relapse over the past  months. And almost one million young people and children are showing an increase in addictive behaviour since the pandemic began.Yet, there is hope. Over the last ten years, I have had the privilege of meeting many incredible people who have lived through the harsh realities of addiction. Through their own hard work, and with the help from communities and charities, such as The Forward Trust, lives really are being turned around.These are stories of healing, of hope and recovery, that can inspire us all.I fully support The ‘Taking Action on Addiction’ campaign to improve awareness and understanding of addiction. The campaign will show us that, not only do many people recover from addiction, they can go on to prosper. Led by the Forward Trust alongside a number of charity partners, Taking Action on Addiction is a long-term campaign which will work to improve awareness and understanding of addiction, its causes and scale in society to enable more people to ask for and receive help.The launch of the new campaign comes as this week is Addiction Awareness Week, which aims to highlight the challenges of addiction and help people and families affected by it.Kate became the patron of the Forward Trust in June, when the charity merged with Action on Addiction, one of her first royal patronages on joining the royal family. news uk-news man-city-star-jack-grealish-"Influencer Paige Rice sadly died in a car crash in LiverpoolByBen PerrinMatthew DreschReporter:,  Oct | commentsEngland footballer Jack Grealish has donated £, towards a fundraiser for a woman killed in a car crash. Paige Rice, , was visiting her boyfriend in Liverpool when they were involved in a crash with a taxi on Sunday morning. The young nail technician has been described as amazing and inspirational in a fundraiser set up to help her family following her death.Grealish has become the top donor on the GoFundMe page after his generous donation, BirminghamLive reports. He posted a aposRIP Paigeapos message on his Instagram account today, underneath a family photo released following her sudden death.He also added a crying face emoji and a broken heart in the touching post.  Paige, from Marston Green, Solihull, died in hospital after she was a passenger in a car which collided with a taxi in the Queensway tunnel in Liverpool. Her partner was driving the Audi S they were travelling in when the smash happened. Her boyfriend is in a aposvery critical conditionapos, while the taxi driver is in a serious but non le-threatening condition. It is understood big-hearted Grealish, , did not know Paige, but it is believed he reached out to one of her friends and offered to help fundraise.  The GoFundMe page for Paigeaposs family has raised £, in just six hours - with the total now standing at almost £,. The fundraiser describes Paige, who worked selling cars and as a nail technician, as amazing and inspirational. She was such an amazing woman with such a clean heart who had so much love to give. Anyone she met she had a huge impact on and a smile that would light up any room, the GoFundMe page said. Mum Clare Rice said her daughter, who has a large following on Instagram, was a beautul woman inside and out, while her smile would light up a room. Paigeaposs mum Clare told BirminghamLive : Paige and myself had spoken recently about death and she told me thatshe died to remember that she lived le to the absolute full. And she did.Paige was visiting her boyfriend in Liverpool when she died. I am still in shock at the moment and the only thing that is keeping me going is the incredible support and lovely tributes that people have left on social media. It shows just how loved she was. story: Man left baffled after finding whole potato in his packet of Kettle Chips crispsDr David Boyce, , was feeling peckish while watching the deer rut in Leicestershire when he reached for a packet of Kettle Chips crisps to find a potato surprise insideDr David Boyce, , was amused to find the survivor potato Image: Dr David Boyce   MEN MediaByAdam LaverShiler Mahmoudi:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA man was left baffled after finding a whole potato inside a packet of crisps. Dr David Boyce, a physics teacher at Uppingham School in Rutland, was shocked when he opened up his bag Kettle Chips only to find a whole potato.Dr Boyce, , was watching the deer rut in Leicestershire when he felt peckish and opened a bag of crisps, Lincolnshire Live reports.The teacher was bewildered after realising the only thing in the packet, was a potato.Posting on Twitter, he said: My mind went completely blank. At first, I thought aposhow is this even in here apos and then I thought aposwhat a champion, this little guy is a survivor - the little potato that refused to be a crisp.aposI still have it. I have yet to decide what to do with it. I thought about scanning it and making a D print of it to incorporate it into a statue reminding me of the glorious moment when I discovered it. Not the greatest moment in my scientic career but Iaposll take what I can get these days.  Kettle Chips has been in touch with Dr Boyce, but he says it may be a while before he eats another packet of crisps. I was left without crisps - that was sad, he joked. Dr Boyce isnapost the only person to have found a surprise in his packet of crisps.Earlier this year, a man found a Hula Hoop crisp that was a whopping cm long when he fancied a snack.Rowan Ulmand, , discovered a long tube of salty, potato goodness in the form of one giant, long Hula Hoop, which measured in at an impressive . centimetres long. The Hula Hoop lover is sure that it must be the longer crisp of its kind in the world, and has warned his family to keep their hands off.Another person was shocked to find just one Wotsit in the bag after he reached for a cheesy snack.Andy Stubbs, , had picked up the packet of crisps only to realise it was full of air. After shaking it around, he soon realised there was just a single cheese puff in the bag, much to the amusement of his we and children. He decided to not open the bag and to keep it as a novelty to make people laugh. story: Met Office issues -hour weather warning for storms and wind sweeping UKThe Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning, urging Brits to prepare for floodwater paired with lightning strikes, hail and strong winds causing building damage between am and midday WednesdayThe Met Office has issued a Yellow Weather Warning for between dawn and midday tomorrow Image: PAByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct Brits are being warned of strong winds and fierce storms sweeping across the UK before midday tomorrow.The Met Office has issued a Yellow Weather Warning for countless locations likely to see storms between Wednesday morning and midday.Heavy rain and thunderstorms are expected to rapidly sweep eastwards across Wales and southwestern England before moving to the centre and east of the country by pm. Rain is expected to lash most of the nation but some areas will be hit worse than others. Some Brits will see lightning strikes and strong, gusty winds rushing at a peak of around -mph. Forecasters warned that much stronger winds are possible here and there and told the public to prepare for structural damage. Meteorologists fear the rapid onset of heavy rain paired with lightning strikes, hail and strong winds could damage homes and businesses across the UK. They predict traffic chaos from the fierce storms, with sudden flooding likely to cause road closures and treacherous conditions.Itaposs likely that public transport will be forced to delay or cancel services altogether, the Met Office said.The weather watchers added that power cuts are also on the cards, with the potential of other services coming to a halt. Trees are also at slight risk of being toppled by the looming strong and gusty winds, the meteorologists say. The Met Office statement reads: Spray and sudden flooding could lead to dficult driving conditions and some road closures Where flooding or lightning strikes occur, there is a chance of delays and some cancellations to train and bus services  There is a slight chance that power cuts could occur and other services to some homes and businesses could be lost There is a small chance of damage to trees by strong and gusty winds. On Monday forecasters warned that  days of stormy weather were looming due to a low pressure front pushing itself over British shores.A polar plunge is also expected to blast Scotlandaposs mountain tops with snow before the end of the week.Rainfalls of up to inches and mph gales are set to hit England, bringing a real risk of severe flooding in some areas. The weather will hold out till the end of the month, meaning unfortunate Brits should prepare for a wet Halloween. Meteorologist for British Weather Services Jim Dale, said the settled conditions weaposve been seeing lately will be replaced by a very turbulent few weeks. He told the Sun : It will turn colder later in the week and there could be a risk of snow whichit comes, will fall over the hills of Scotland. The stormy pattern is expected to hold out until end of the month with a very wet, windy, and possibly stormy, Halloween on the cards. It is time to get ready for a big change in the weather with a real witches brew in the run up to Halloween, he added. Milder air pushing from the south throughout Monday and Tuesday, however, will also be at play, meaning places like London could see temperatures reach C. Over in Scotland, people should prepare for a polar plunge as first substantial snowfall is expected on the high ground from am on Thursday, the Daily Record reports. Bitter -C days are due, with frosts and freezing nights for some. Lows hit -.C this weekend at Redesdale Camp, Northumberland. news uk-news most-popular-baby-names-year-"Baby names likely to be popular in  according to expertsByJessica TaylorReal le features writer:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsItaposs a question that causes squabbling among all new parents - which name should you give to your newborn baby  Never an easy decision, itaposs something that takes careful consideration and will stay with a child for their entire le. But when it comes to choosing baby names in the UK, it seems many parents tend to think alike - with several favourite names seeming to top the charts every year. Names like Amelia and Isla often top the list of girlsapos names, with Jack and James always being firm favourites for newborn boys.  And the top choice for both girls and boys remains unchanged this year - with Olivia and Oliver taking first preference among parents in England and Wales for the eighth year in a row. However, it seems these names tend to be most popular with older parents, as the data also showed that younger parents favoured shorter names like Leo and Theo for boys and Ava and Ivy for girls.  For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Data from the Office for National Statistics shows that, for both boysapos and girlsapos names, the top  was slightly changed. Whereas Grace and Freya made the shortlist the previous year,  data shows those favourites had been replaced by Ivy and Rosie.And Charlie was knocked out of the top  for boysapos names for the first time since  - being replaced by Archie, which could have been influenced by Prince Harry and Meghan Markleaposs son. Whataposs your favourite baby name  Have your say in the comment section below. Statistics from the last  years show boysapos names Arthur and Noah have soared up the ranks in popularity to rank in the top five in . The two biggest climbers for boysapos names in  were Milo and Otis, which went up by about  places. According to the ONS, parents over the age of  were more likely to choose traditional names while younger parents tended to choose modern, shortened names. Sian Bradford from the ONS said: Oliver and Olivia held on to the top spots as the most popular boysapos and girlsapos names in  but some interesting changes took place beneath them. We continue to see the age of mothers having an impact on the choice of baby name. Archie jumped into the top  boysapos names for the first time, driven by younger mothers as well as the obvious royal link, while on the girlsapos side, Ivy rose to sixth place. Popular culture continues to provide inspiration for baby names, whether itaposs characters in our favourite show or trending celebrities. Maeve and Otis, characters from the popular programme Sex Education, have seen a surge in popularity in , while the name Margot has been rapidly climbing since actress Margot Robbie appeared in the popular film The Wolf Of Wall Street. title: mum 25 accused neglect leaving
story: Mum, , accused of neglect for leaving five-week-old baby with her gran overnightZoe Wallace, , typically shares TikTok videos to her thousands of followers as a busy mum-of-two but in a recent one she received an avalanche of online abuse about her youngest child Parker having a sleepover with her granZoe Wallace was criticised on TikTok after sharing how her youngest daughter Parker spent the night at her grans when she was five weeks old Image: Manchester Evening NewsByEmma GillAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct | commentsA mum has been accused of neglect after leaving her five-week-old baby with a grandparent overnight.Zoe Wallace, , typically shares TikTok videos to her thousands of followers documenting her le as a busy mum with two kids. Her recent video hit more than seven million views and resulted in her receiving horric abuse online,Manchester Evening News reports. The mum, from Wigan, told her followers about her daughter Parker falling ill RSV - or respiratory syncytial virus - when she was five weeks old. RSV is a viral illness that causes symptoms such as breathing problems and can lead to more severe bronchiolitis and pneumonia in young babies. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter She describes how Parker, who is now four months old, had to be moved from AE to a high dependency unit where she was put on a machine to do the breathing for her. The youngster was diagnosed with a severe chest infection but thankfully began to recover with the help of antibiotics. In the video, she had also said Parker spent the night with her gran - who lives a -minute drive away, before falling ill.  Many TikTok users blasted the mum for letting Parker have her first sleepover with her gran the night before she fell ill. One wrote: Jesus, five weeks and you are done with it already  Poor child isnapost gonna grow up the best. Another said: This is neglect. How could you do that to your newborn. Zoe has shared her own video hitting back at the comments. She told MEN: I posted the video originally to share my daughter’s story with RSV.  It made her very poorly and I was unaware how serious it could be in newborns. I hadn’t even heard about it until she was poorly and I wanted to make other mums aware of the signs. I had mentioned that she stayed with my mum the night before falling ill to show how quickly she declined but it wasn’t taken that way. People in the comments have branded me a bad mum because of my decision to allow my mum to have my child overnight.  To me, personally, it’s pretty normal for new mums to get support in anyway from family members but I didn’t know it would be so controversial online. I do regret mentioning her staying at my mumaposs because of the hate I have received, but I don’t regret sharing my daughteraposs story, because it could help save another child’s le. Zoe, who also has a three-year-old son Dominic with partner David Hunt, , also spoke about some of the disgusting comments she received. She said: The most hurtful is that I’m neglecting my children, I’m a bad parent, that my daughter deserved to die because she wouldn’t have bad parents. That I don’t deserve children or I shouldn’t have childrenI’m too lazy to look after them. The main hate I received was along the lines of aposhow could you leave your babyapos  It just shocked me how it’s encouraged as a new mum to accept help from people you trust because it can be overwhelming, but as soon as you do it’s seen as neglectful. I think the video going viral has proven the double standards for mums, there’s a lot of mum shaming and I don’t think it’s fair. Zoe, who is on maternity leave from her job at McDonaldaposs, said sheaposs been more willing to accept help from her mum with Parker as she was reluctant with Dominic despite suffering from postnatal depression. Zoe first started posting videos to TikTok during the lockdown and now has more than , followers. She said: I will carry on with it because at the end of the day itaposs my choice ultimately - my kids are fine and my kids are happy. They love spending time with my mum and what other people think is not going to change that, or change what Iaposm posting either. I have people who follow me and they chat to me daily and say they like seeing the content so I wonapost let this stop me. title: mum who took mercedes car
story: Mum who took Mercedes to car wash after son shot love rival on back seat jailedPatricia Dean, , was sentenced to  months in prison after being found guilty of assisting an offender. The shooting happened in a car leased by Dean through the NHS, the court heardPatricia Dean pictured with her son Vincenzo De Falco Image: Patricia Dean  Cavendish PressLtdByThomas MolloyChiara Fiorillo:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA mum who took her Mercedes to a car wash after her son shot a love rival on the back seat of the vehicle has been jailed. Patricia Dean, , was sentenced to  months in prison after being found guilty of assisting an offender. Prosecution barrister Philip Barnes said the womanaposs son, Vincenzo De Falco, shot his victim while parked up in Rochdale, Greater Manchester, on January , .The court heard the car where the shooting took place was leased by Dean through the NHS and she allowed her son to drive it as and when he needed it, the Manchester Evening News reports.De Falcoaposs victim was previously in a relationship with his girlfriend Lucy Flux and the pair had been texting over the New Year period, the court heard. On the afternoon of the shooting, the victim had travelled to buy some cannabis from De Falco. When the pair met, De Falco confronted the victim about his contact with Ms Flux and allegedly shouted: “You think I’m some sort of muppet.” The victim reassured De Falco that he was just friends with Ms Flux and that there was nothing to worry about. However, the court heard De Falco then said “You want to get shot” and the victim noticed a shotgun pointed towards him. He grabbed the barrel of the gun to turn it away from him and shortly after, De Falco told another man to let the victim out of the car. As he shuffled across the back seat to leave, De Falco shot the victim in the leg at point-blank range, the court heard. The man was then dumped out of the car onto the pavement where passers-by called an ambulance. After the attack, the victim had to have his leg amputated below the knee, Bolton Crown Court heard.  De Falco, who admitted causing grievous bodily harm with intent, will be sentenced at a later date. Mental health nurse Dean had been working at North Manchester General Hospital on the day of the shooting and had only recently arrived back at her home in Sowerby Bridge, Yorkshire, when she received a call from Ms Flux. Dean immediately left her house to drive to Ms Flux’s home in Bacup, Lancashire, in her other car - a BMW. They spent around  minutes at the house before Ms Flux and Dean left in one car, while De Falco and a man left in another. Later that night, De Falco and Dean both drove along the same route in separate cars while communicating on the phone.  The next day, Dean took the Mercedes to a hand car wash in Heywood where three car wash employees spent more than an hour cleaning the Mercedes. The following day police stopped Deanaposs BMW in Middleton, North Manchester. De Falco was also in the car and both were arrested. When the Mercedes was inspected, traces of the victim’s blood were found on the door and mat, the court heard. During her interview, Dean denied knowing anything about what De Falco had done.  She told police that the car had not been washed since the weekend before the shooting but her trip to the car wash in Heywood was caught on CCTV. Defending, William Donnelly told the court that Dean was a woman of impeccable character. She worked as a nurse for more than  years and former colleagues described her as committed, honest, caring, reliable, and compassionate in character references heard by the court. Mr Donnelly said that Dean had continued to work as a nurse while on bail during the pandemic but recently found out that she has lost her job and will lose her pension too. Jailing her, Judge Tom Gilbart said: “It is absolutely mystying that a woman with such a history of care and public service would throw it all away in such a manner. “It really is such a waste to see you in the dock of a court. “You’ve continued to deny the offence in discussing matters with the probation service. “You told the author of the report, ‘I cannot be sorry for what I have been convicted of because I didn’t do it’.” Comment MORE ON Court caseCrown courtCrime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Pub landlord vows to stop Britain running out of Nigels with record-breaking Nige-festLandlord Nigel Smith has vowed to save Britain from running out of Nigels by throwing a record breaking Nige-fest with prizes for newborn Nigels and free pints for all named Nigel Nigel Parker  Nigel Hallett. Nigel Smith aged , landlord of the The Fleece Inn, Bretforton, Worcester, breaks the world record for the largest ever gathering of Nigels in one place with a total number of . See SWNS story SWMDnigel. A pub landlord has broken the world record for the largest gathering of Nigels in one place, to try and stop the name dying out. Nigel Smith, , came up with the idea in  after no new-borns were called Nigel that year.  Nigels from all over the world got together at the Fleece Inn, Bretforton, Worcs., for an evening of Nigel-themed refreshment and entertainment." content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _SWNS_NIGEL_NIGHT_.jpg" width"" "" Nigel Parkerand Nigel Hallettat Nigel Smiths Nige-fest as Smith has sworn to save the name Nigel from extinction Image: Dave Evitts   SWNSByNigel IskanderKieren Williams:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA pub landlord has vowed to save Britain from running out of Nigels after it was revealed the name was going extinct.The latestOffice for National Statistics data has shown that no boys were called Nigel in  , and that the name may be going extinct.In response, pub landlord Nigel Smith has vowed to throw the world’s biggest ‘Nige-fest’ to help save the name. Nigel came up with the idea after the new data was released, in a desperate effort to save the name from the annals of history. The -year-old is inviting Nigels from across the world for a celebration that would see prizes given for parents who name their children Nigel. Nigel has promised a free pint for every Nigel who can provide ID as well.  The call to arms of Nigels everywhere emerged after the new data showed that there were no new Nigels last year. However,anyone were to stop this trend, it would be Nigel, who runs the Fleece Inn in Bretforton. He currently holds the world record for the largest gathering of Nigels when  Nigels joined him for a pint in . Every attendee brought photo ID and signed ‘The Book of Nigel’ to allow the Guiness Book of Records to very their achievement.  Now he wants to smash his own record and is planning a weekend Nige-fest at his pub next year. Nigel said: It started as a laugh to get Nigels together. There were no Nigels registered in  so I thought it would be a good idea to get us all together. When I found out no new Nigels were born in  I got worried and was determined to celebrate the name before it dies out. Weaposve sent the word out across the world to get as many Nigels here as we possibly can.  Theyaposll be prizes for anyone who has named their child Nigel and for any expectant mums who promise to name their sons Nigel too. In the year I was born, , there were over , Nigels born. It was peak Nigel. It was so ubiquitous and it became much-maligned. At school I used to have the mickey taken out of me. Iaposve got two children and neither are called Nigel. I think names are cyclical and itaposs gone out of fashion. A lot of people donapost like the name but I think we can make it popular again.  Nigel, who runs the pub with partner Tash, , believes one of the reasons the name has become so unpopular is down to ex-UKIP leader Nigel Farage. He added: I think we can get the name back in vogue again. When we held the Nigel record attempt in  we had a Nigel come all the way over from Texas. Weaposre hoping to smash the record next year. All our rooms are booked for the weekend and we hope to get over , Nigels here. title: queen politely firmly turns down
story: Queen politely but firmly turns down rare award as she doesnt meet criteriaThe Queen declined an honour from The Oldie of the Year Awards saying "you are only as old as you feel". As she approaches her Platinum Jubilee, the monarch has been on sparkling form in recent monthsThe Queen turned down an honour from The Oldie of the Year Awards Image: Getty ImagesByRussell MyersRoyal editorChiara Fiorillo:,  Oct | commentsThe Queen has “politely but firmly” turned down an honour from The Oldie of the Year Awards because she “didn’t believe she met the relevant criteria” to accept. The -year-old monarch graciously declined the award, stating that “you are only as old as you feel”. Author and broadcaster Gyles Brandreth, chairman of the awards, wrote to her private secretary Sir Edward Young to askshe would accept the main Oldie of the Year. But in a letter published in the November issue of the magazine, her assistant private secretary Tom Laing-Baker wrote: “Her Majesty believes you are as old as you feel, as such The Queen does not believe she meets the relevant criteria to be able to accept and hopes you will find a more worthy recipient.” As she approaches her Platinum Jubilee next year, the Queen has been on sparkling form in recent months, entertaining world leaders, attending the races and mastering the very modern ritual of the video call. This year, her daughter-in-law the Duchess of Cornwall has joined Gyles Brandreth for the publication’s first in-person awards ceremony since  at The Savoy Hotel in London. For the past  years, The Oldie of The Year Awards has celebrated the achievements of those of the older generation who have made a special contribution to public le. Previous winners have included everyone from Oscar winners to Nobel laureates, from community care nurses to veteran athletes, from Sir John Major to Dame Olivia de Havilland and David Hockney. Last year, the principal Oldie of the Year award went to Petula Clark, whose eight-decade career in showbusiness skyrocketed during the Blitz.It comes after reports that the Queen was annoyed that planet-polluting leaders may skip a UN climate summit.Her Majesty will attend the COP in Glasgow with Princes Charles and William, who says son George worries about litter. She said of world leaders such as Russia’s President Putin failing to commit: “It’s irritating.” The leaders of countries including China and Russia have been dubbed “irritating” by the Queen for failing to commit to next month’s UN climate change conference. The monarch, , spoke of her dismay just weeks before global heads of state and environmentalists including activist Greta Thunberg discuss the climate emergency at the COP in Glasgow. MacMillan Academy in Middlesbrough, North Yorkshire is really struggling with staffing levels after Covid infections hit staff and students.The school will also reinstate face masks in communal areas from Tuesday, Teeside Live reports.In a letter to parents and carers, Head of School Rachel Coning wrote of making a very dficult decision toYear  classes to online s until Friday. Supply teachers have been filling the gaps left by sick staff but it is not going to be enough for the rest of this week. It is not out of the question that we will have to ask another year group to also work from home later in the week, I will let you knowthis needs to be the case, she added.  The letter states: As recent communication has indicated, the number of COVID cases in the academy has increased recently and this has affected both staff and students. For the first time in the pandemic we are really struggling with staffing levels. Over the last week or so we have had to call on a number of supply teachers but even that is not going to be enough for the rest of this week. Therefore we have made the very dficult decision to move Year  students to online learning from tomorrow for the rest of the week. Year  have made a great start to the year and we know they will work very hard independently. We are also conscious that we do not want to create childcare issues for parents and that is why we have chosen Year . Unfortunately, due to the fact that staff in the building will be covering other lessons, we cannot deliver live Teams lessons to Year  and work will be set on Frog. If your child has any issues at all then please encourage them to get in touch with their teachers. It is not out of the question that we will have to ask another year group to also work from home later in the week, I will let you knowthis needs to be the case. The school has also been in consultation with Public Health England over the use of face masks in school. The letter continues: In addition, it will come as no surprise that in consultation with public health, from tomorrow we will be reinstating the wearing of face masks in all communal areas. story: Exclusive: Student, , spiked with injection woke up confused with no memory of night outZara Owen, , who found a pin-prick after she blacked out on a night out in Pryzm, Nottingham, tells the Mirror that the fear of being spiked has always been thereZara Owen, , from Surrey, woke up in agony with bruising and a pin-prick Image: Zara OwenByShiler Mahmoudi:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA university student spiked with an injection has shared her horrendous experience of waking up confused with no memory of the night out. Last Monday, Zara Owen, , from Surrey who is a student at the University of Nottingham was on a night out at Pryzm, Nottingham, with her friends. Upon entering the club and going through security, she went to get a drink from the bar, but that is where her memories of that night end. The next thing she remembers is waking up the next morning without any recollection of what had happened after the entered the club, something that had never happened to her before. Speaking to the Mirror, Zara said: I was originally really confused because I woke up with no memory of the night. That is something that never happens to me and it was confusing since I hadnapost drank much alcohol. When it hit me I had been spiked, I was so shocked to realise this had happened to me as I take the safety measures given very seriously. I cover my glasses and I cover my bottles to make sure nothing goes in, but to realise I had been injected is terrying. She says that nothing was out of the ordinary at first, but she had woken up with a sharp, agonising pain in her leg and was walking with a limp. After speaking to her friends, they informed her that she had been acting out of character, not making any sense and wandering off alone. Thankfully, a friend was able to get her home safely after spotting her outside the club where she had walked off and was speaking incoherently. The next morning, she was shocked to find a pin-prick after examining her leg properly. I had been spiked, she wrote in a post on Twitter.Zara went to the hospital to have her leg checked out, but was left waiting for hours. Sharing her experience, she said: Obviously with needles, you can catch HIV or hepatitis.  I went to the hospital and I had triage and was asked some background questions. That was it, I sat waiting and assumed Iaposd be seen. After sitting in AE for eight hours, she gave up and went home as she had an early start and she had been there all night. I rang my GP the next day and explained what happened, but they could only give me an appointment for two weeks time. I called up the phlebotomy who said you need to have paperwork to be checked. I canapost get paperworkno-one will see me. By the time I will see the GP it will be two weeks. If I am carrying anything it will be too late.  Zara decided to inform the police a few days after what happened. I spoke to the police on Saturday after work and they came to my house that night for a statement, she said. They recorded everything and said theyaposd take a urine sample, but they texted me the next day to say I didnapost need to hand it in as it had been too long. Obviously, itaposs going to be hard to find out who the culprit was. When asking her about what she thinks should be done to tackle incidences of spiking in clubs and bars, Zara highlighted the need to have competent and thorough security staff and measures. She told the Mirror: For me it comes down to security. More security in checking - Iaposve been to clubs before and I havenapost been searched. Itaposs so beneficial and people shouldnapost be able to bring in these substances and the security should check. She also highlighted the need for security to ensure they are actively monitoring the crowd and looking out for any behaviour that can cause harm to women. Zara explained that going forward, she will naturally be more aware of her surroundings. She added: One of my main fears is being spiked, or my friends being spiked on a night out. Thataposs always been there. Now itaposs happened to me, itaposs much stronger in my mind. Iaposll be more aware and make sure [my friends] are all okay. Iaposm lucky enough that Iaposm fine and didnapost end up in hospital or worse. The fear factor is still there but I would like to think that I can go out and measures will be in place so I can have a stress free evening. I donapost know what weaposre supposed to do.  Unfortunately, Zara is not the only person to have been spiked through an injection.Leeds Studentsapos Group, which is a student Facebook page that has over  thousand members across all of Leedsapos universities, has had a number of people warning that women had been injected.Students posted about feeling sharp pinches and later finding pin-pricks on their bodies while on nights out. There were reports of this happening in nightclubs that are popular among students, such as Beaver Works, Mint, TenBar and O Academy Leeds. Speaking to the Mirror about her experience at an event at O Academy Leeds, one woman said: I was in a large crowd and I felt something sharp go into my thigh. About five people were trying to squeeze past my group at that point so I didnapost really think much of it as I thought one of them had accidentally scratched me.  I was fine the whole night but when I got home my thigh ached and had a needle puncture in it and bruising. [Iaposm] guessing someone tried to spike me but it didnapost work. It was definitely an IM injection like an epi-pen.It made me feel sick that this this is what people are resorting to. God knows what they want to do to these young women but I don’t want to think about it! Bars and clubs need to do thorough checks of pockets and bags on doors and high quality security cameras around the place to deter this sort of behaviour.Ellie Patrick, , from London had her drink spiked while at Walkabout in Leeds, which caused her to have a fall on her shoulder and knees. Speaking on how the incident impacted her, she told the Mirror: The next day I was extremely sick and unwell all day. I had a bad headache and was hot and cold.I went to the hospital that evening just to seeI was okay. Unfortunately, I never got in touch with anyone about this experience because it scared me quite a bit and I just wanted to put it behind me.I had also heard about previous experiences of people being spiked at Walkabout and the venue not doing anything to help the situation.I also did not inform the police as I wasn’t surethey’d take the case seriously since I had no evidence I was spiked.So sadly thereaposs no follow up, I do wish I had done something about it. A University of Nottingham spokesperson said: “The University and Students’ Union are concerned by these reports and are working closely with Nottinghamshire Police and the city’s nightle venues.We would encourage our students to be additionally vigilant and follow police advice to report any suspicions to them immediately for investigationStudent welfare is our top priority and we already run a range of schemes to support students’ personal safety when on a night out. Detective Superintendent Paula Bickerdike, of West Yorkshire Police’s Safeguarding Central Governance Unit, said: “We understand the genuine concerns that women have around their safety, particularly in the night-time economy, and we remain absolutely committed to doing everything we can alongside our partner agencies to make the county a safer place for women and girls. “We continue to work alongside partner agencies and licensees to warn and educate people about staying safe on a night out, and we conduct regular partnership operations to keep people safe.” The West Yorkshire Police added: [We] have received one report of ‘spiking by injection’, reported to have occurred in Leeds city centre on October , . We have spoken to the victim about this matter and enquiries are currently ongoing into the incident. What to doyou suspect you have been injected or spiked: The NHS website provides some guidelines on what to doyour skin has been punctured with a used needle. They advise to aposwash the wound using running water and plenty of soapapos, aposdry the wound and cover it with a waterproof plaster or dressingapos and to not scrub the wound or suck any blood. Nottingham Policeaposs websites has some guidance on what to doyour drink has been spiked, but they currently do not have any guidelines on being injected. They advise to: Tell the people you’re with and make sure you’re someone where you feel safe. Alert a member of staff at the pub or club you are at. If you feel unwell you should seek medical attention immediately and tell them that you believe your drink has been spiked. Girls Against, a non-profit organisation that campaigns against sexual assault at music events, has provided some tips for venues.  Speaking to the Mirror, it said: Our main piece of advice to venues is to train all venue staff on how to appropriately and efficiently handle such situations - what signs to be aware of [and] what medical advice to be aware of. No one who has been spiked via injection or otherwise should be made to feel guilty or asthe event was their fault. West Yorkshire Police and Nottingham Police have been contacted for comment. The University of Leeds has also been contacted for comment. story: UK is a nation of ketchup lovers – but ided over how we eat favourite chip dipWhile eight in  are adamant a dollop of tomato sauce on the side of the plate to dip food in to is best, two in  prefer to smother their mealThe survey of , adults by frozen food giant Birds Eye found chips were the most popular food to go with a condiment, with dippers second and nachos third Image: Getty ImagesByRuki SayidConsumer Editor:,  Oct | commentsThe UK is a nation of ketchup lovers – but we’re ided over what to do with the stuff. While eight in  are adamant a dollop of tomato sauce on the side of the plate to dip food in to is best, two in  prefer to smother their meal. More than half felt squirting ketchup all over a dish was bad manners and an insult to the chef. The survey of , adults by frozen food giant Birds Eye found chips were the most popular food to go with a condiment, with dippers second and nachos third. But dipping food into someone ’s sauce was seen as a faux pax by half while ketchup or mayo with a roast was a no-no for almost  per cent. And four in  fussy eaters frowned on mixing two sauces together on a plate. Ketchup was crowned king of the condiments, followed by mayonnaise barbecue and chilli sauce.  Annalisa Fanali, marketing manager for Chicken Dippers at Birds Eye, said: “Our research shows just how important a dip or a sauce is, with many saying that a meal is simply not complete without a condiment. “We weren’t surprised to see that ketchup still reigns supreme when it comes to our favourite thing to dip or dunk our food into.” Birds Eye, who commissioned the survey are on the hunt for a new CDO, a Chief Dipping Officer. The position requires an inidual with outstanding taste buds and has a solid background in sauce ratios.  The chosen candidate will receive a year’s supply of Birds Eye Chicken Dippers, £, in cash and will be required to oversee the Birds Eye social media channels. A spokesperson for Birds Eye said, “We’re really excited to be on the hunt for our new Chief Dipping Officer and we’re looking forward to seeing what hopefuls think they can bring to the job, as well as providing some expert dipping tips to share with the nation.” Top :  Ketchup  Mayonnaise  BBQ sauce  Chilli sauce  Salsa  Brown sauce  Salad cream  Guacamole  Soy sauce  Mustard Comment MORE ON Birds EyeFoodCelebrity kids" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: what red sky morning mean
story: What does a red sky in the morning mean  Truth behind the ‘shepherd’s warning’ rhymeThe ‘shepherd’s warning’ is an old rhyme which hints that a red sky means bad weather is on its way. Did you notice a red sky this morning  Here’s what it really meansA stunning ed sky over Blyth, Northumberland Image: PAByMalvika Padin:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsWinter mornings are hard, the pitch-black sky making it dficult to wake up and start your day. But when the sun finally comes up, have you noticed that the sky is often tinged pink or red If you’ve ever heard some iation of the ‘shepherd’s warning’ rhyme, this may be the first thing that pops into your head. If you havenapost this is how it goes – ‘Red sky at night – shepherd’s’ delight  Red sky in the morning – shepherd’s take warning.’But what does a red sky really mean  Why does it happen  And does it actually impact the weather  If you’ve ever asked any of these questions, then here are all the answers you’re looking for.Why does the sky turn red in the morning  Periods of high pressure during winter can lead to cold, dry days, with light winds. These winds cause dust and other particles to become trapped within the atmosphere.This means that when the sunlight moves through the sky, the red waves pass through the air more easily than blue ones tend to deflect and get scattered, leaving the sky tinged red.Did you have a stunning red sky this morning  Let us know in the comments belowSometimes, when the red light is reflected on white clouds it gives the appearance of pink clouds as well. What does the ‘shepherd’s warning’ rhyme have to do with the red sky  For over  years, shepherd’srhyme – which also appears in the Bible - has been used as a rule of thumb for predicting the weather. The aposshepherd’s warningapos means that the weather following a day with a red sky was going to be poor – something which shepherds and sailors both had reason to be wary of.Is the ‘shepherd’s warning’ rhyme true  Despite the science behind the red sky, the ‘shepherd’s warning’ rhyme does hold some truth to it as well, as long as you’re somewhere along the middle latitudes of the planet. In the UK, weather systems move predominantly from west to east. A red sky in the morning therefore means that the sky is clear to the east, where the sun is rising, but cloudy overhead. This suggests that the clouds are beginning to move in bringing in bad weather with it. Meanwhile, a red sky at sunset means high pressure is moving in from the west and therefore the next day will usually be dry and pleasant. However, in the tropics, where the winds blow in the opposite direction, the saying about red skies doesn’t work. story: Man pushes ahead with gory Halloween display despite multiple police visitsArtist Steven Novak was visited by police several times last year after people were left terried by his gruesome Halloween display – but he’s back at it again this yearSteven is upping the ante this year with a blood-spurting wood chipper Image: Avi Adelman ZUMA Press Wire REX ShutterstockByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Oct | commentsLast year, an artist named Steven Novak made headlines for his gruesome Halloween display which saw murdered mannequins littered across his front lawn in a realistic bloodbath. The display was so gory it prompted several passersby to call the police after thinking they’d stumbled across an actual crime scene. And even though he was visited by officers multiple times last year, Steven has vowed to put his decorations up once again at his home in Dallas, Texas – especially in light of the “rough” year many have faced.Speaking to the Dallas Observer, he said: “This year has been rough for a lot of people. I think we can agree that this project is ing as a pressure release valve.” Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Steven is even encouraging police to turn up to his house again this year. He added: “All the cops that came out last year were an absolute gas. I welcome them to come out and take more selfies.” The artist has said many of the fan-favourite decorations from last year will be make a reappearance in his upcoming display – but there will be plenty of new details on display too. He explained: “Last year’s hits remain: the safe, ladder, chainsaw, Roof Guy and my girlfriend. Also the fake blood made of corn syrup on the sidewalk.  “But there are lots of new details -gallon drums are now out by the curb filled up with the shredded party [of guests]. And I made the body parts this year by cutting up mannequins then filling them with skeleton parts and Great Stuff insulation foam.” The centrepiece of his display this year is a refurbished wood chipper that spits out fake blood across his lawn and into a paddling pool covered in shredded mannequin remains. He said of the new addition: “There are lots of new gimmicks to this year’s caper. The wood chipper blood fountain being the clear centrepiece and easily the most challenging prop. It took me months to find an old wood chipper for sale. The sellers were not pleased with its new purpose.” And Steven is even being conscious about the environment with his display, as the woodchipper and fountain are set up in a way that doesn’t waste water.  He added: “It’s all powered by a submersible water pump inside the [kiddie] pool which then leads back to the wood chipper fountain. You can turn that pump on with your foot by pressing a hidden pedal switch.” If that wasn’t enough to ensure the artist wins all the awards for best Halloween display, he’s also created an optical illusion with a second front door that makes it look like his house has been broken into by an axe-wielding maniac. He said: “I bought a door, matched the house paint, smashed it, and mounted it to swing out on hinges. “The real door to my house behind it, I then painted with a product called Black . that reflects very little light, so it almost looks invisible.” Steven has spent a small fortune on his gory display this year, and is welcoming donations through his Venmo account, @stevenallennovak. And despite the time and money it takes to set up the impressive scene, Steven is determined to go even bigger next year. He said: “It’s been a tremendous amount of work and dough, but it’s worth it because people love it so much. People get as tickled looking at my massacre as they do looking at puppies! story: Former Home Bargains employee shares customer hacks - including best time to shopA woman who worked at Home Bargains for four months has shared her secrets to shopping savvy – including the best time of year to bag the biggest bargainsHome Bargains dont often give discounts - but you could still save money by shopping smarter Image: Katie PughByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Oct | commentsWe all love a bargain when we’re out shopping, and one of the best places to go to bag a decent saving is the store with it literally in the name – Home Bargains. But did you know you could save yourself even more money at the homeware shop just by visiting at specic times of the year A former employee of the franchise, Jessica Harrison, has shared some of the store’s secrets on her TikTok account, the Daily Star reports. In one video the -year-old student – whose TikTok account is @Jesss.Harrisonxx – reeled off a list of questions which all had the answer “no”, including: “Do you do cash back ”, “Can I push the till barrier open ”, “Can I see the manager ”, and the infamous “Can you seeyou have any more in the back ”.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. But Jessica, who worked at Home Bargains for four months throughout the Easter period this year, also lted the lid on some money-saving secrets – including when the best time to shop is. According to Jessica, you can bag better dealsyou shop at the end of the season, as items will be reduced to help get rid of leftover stock. She said: “So just after Christmas is your best time to grab bits for the following year!  “I worked throughout the Easter period and when Easter was over, all of the decorations were drastically reduced in price.”Outside of items being reduced, Jessica – who also shared tips on her Instagram account – says it’s pretty hard to get a discount in store.She explained: “Discounts are only given when there is something wrong with the item, for examplethere is a piece missing or something could be broken. “They are quite strict with when discounts are given, and the shop floor staff always have to ask a manager before telling a customer they can have something at a reduced rate. “ And the former employee also has the best tip for tracking down an item that just isn’t available in your local store. title: man told trim obscene bush
story: Man told to trim ‘obscene’ bush that flips-off punters at pub opposite his homeRichard Jenkins, , has displayed the -ft rude topiary in his front garden for the last  years but says he has been ordered to trim it or tear it down after a complaintGardener Richard Jackson, , with his nicknamed Warton Bush Image: Tristan Potter   SWNSByRosaleen FentonAudience Writer:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA cheeky gardener has been told to stop beating around the bush and tear down an aposobsceneapos hedge in his front garden. Richard Jenkins has been warned he faces police actionhe doesnapost chop down his ft hedge - which has been carved into a hand flipping the middle finger. The -year-old was stunned when council chiefs ordered it to tear it down after displaying the rude topiary for the last  years. He initially carved it as a joke for punters who teased him as he cut the hedges at a pub opposite his home in the village of Warton, Warks.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter here The middle-finger bush now attracts a younger crowd too - with Instagram and TikTok fans desperate to share it on social media.So Richard, who has two grown-up children and four grandchildren, was baffled when he learnt the authorities wanted it removed. It follows a complaint from a resident living nearby which prompted Warwickshire County Council to write to him threatening legal action.  But Richard has remained defiant and locals who love the hedge have even launched a ‘Save the Warton Bush’ campaign. He said: It all started years ago as a bit of a laugh with the locals in the nearby pub. I used to do the hedges over there and they’d give me a bit of a tease when they came out. “One day I thought I’d get my own back so cut the hedge into a giant middle finger. The pub locals thought it was hilarious and it just went from there. It became a permanent fixture in the village.  “Everything was fine until I got a letter from the council saying someone had complained, saying the hedge was obscene. “I was told I’d have to cut it down or mody it so it didn’t look rude anymore. I refused so they got the police involved. A policeman came out and saidthey received any more complaints then I’d be instantly fined.“He even suggested I turn it into a fist but I told him no way. I still didn’t do anything about the hedge apart from let it grow out a bit but there’s no way I’d chop it down. “It was all for a laugh.” Richard and his we of  years, Linda, , live opposite The Office Pub in the village with the hedge pointing towards the entrance. He added: Many people quite like it, often you see you people stopping in their cars, getting out and having a picture with it. One local lad even has it as his screensaver on his phone. I have had it up for nearly  years now, it is staying. Warwickshire Police confirmed an officer was sent to investigate although they had not received a direct complaint. story: Woman asked to remove brooch at work as it leaves colleague feeling distressedA woman has been asked to take off the sparkly rhinestone brooch she wore to her workplace after the design left one of her co-workers “distressed” and terriedThe woman bought a brooch for Halloween but was told to ditch itImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Oct | comments We all have things we’re scared of, and with Halloween right around the corner, many of us are having to confront the things that go bump in the night.But one woman has been forced to ditch one of her spooky season accessories after it left her co-worker horried. Posting on Mumsnet, the woman explained she often wears brooches to work and had recently bought a dazzling rhinestone spider brooch, which she wore for the first time last week. And just a few hours into her sht, the woman was approached by her manager and asked to take off her accessory – because it was terrying one of her colleagues who has a phobia of spiders.She explained: “I quite often wear brooches and yesterday wore a new one to work. It is from Zara and is a reasonably large sparkly rhinestone spider, which I had pinned to a black jumper.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. “Mid-morning my line manager approached and askedI would be prepared to take the brooch off as a colleague had said that they have a phobia and was finding it distressing. “I took it off my jumper and put it on my coat, which I didnapost wear again until I left for the day.” The woman doesn’t know who the complaint came from, but insisted she’s never heard of any of her colleagues suffering from arachnophobia before now. She added: “The complaint will have come from one of three people, based on who saw me yesterday morning.  “Iaposm not going to go digging to find out who it was, and I donapost want to cause anyone distressbut Iaposve worked with all three of them for several years and this severe phobia has never come up before. “I donapost want to be a d*** but equally I really like my brooch.” The post has over  comments, and opinion has been ided over whether the woman should stop wearing the brooch. One person wrote: “Itaposs a brooch, not a pet tarantula. They are being ridiculous.” And another agreed, adding: “Fear of real spiders is one thing, fear of a piece of jewellery is quite another.” But several others sided with the colleague, insisting a fear of spiders doesn’t necessarily stop at the real thing. Someone said: “If someone has a real phobia of spiders, itaposs not inconceivable that they canapost even mention the word. “There are ying degrees of arachnophobia, and for some people they canapost tolerate seeing the word spider written down or seeing images . “A phobia is an irrational fear of something, so just because it doesnapost make sense to you, doesnapost make it any less traumatic for them.” While another wrote: “My colleague has a spider phobia. There is no way she could have spent the day looking at that brooch. Just knowing it was there would have been enough. “Phobias arenapost rational and go way beyond just not liking them.” And a third posted: “It would be unreasonable to wear it to work in the future now you know it causes distress to a colleague.”What do you think  Let us know in the comments.
