title: horrific real life squid game
story: Horric real-le Squid Game sees thousands of prisoners harvested for organs ALIVEWARNING: UPSETTING CONTENT. Tens of thousands of dissidents and political prisoners are reportedly harvested in China every year as part of a barbaric black market operation led by the Chinese governmentA Falun Gong follower displays torture methods they claim Chinese authorities used against their members in China Image: ReutersByAlex BellottiNews Features Writer:,  Oct | commentsCalled to a remote hillside on a hot summeraposs day, Dr Enver Tothi felt a chill down his spine as gunshots rang out across the fields. Walking his team over the summit, the medical expert was greeted by the sight of up to  men wearing prisonersapos unorms collapsed leless on the ground. Their heads had been blown off by military police who stood over twitching corpses - the job of Dr Tothi was to harvest fresh organs, which have become a valuable commodity on the Chinese black market. The horric scenes may sound eerily similarly to the side plot in Netflixaposs smash hit drama Squid Game, but the gruesome practice is all too real.Human rights groups in China claim the government is operating an organ-trafficking network that harvests as many as , dissidents and political prisoners every year.Hearts, kidneys, livers and even corneas are all removed on an industrial scale, campaigners say - while those involved have revealed grim secrets of witnessing the barbaric scenes first-hand. Organs aposharvestedapos like in Netflix hit Since its release last month, Squid Game has quickly become the most-viewed international show in Netflixaposs history. The creepy South Korean thriller sees desperate contestants battle it out in childhood-inspired games to win millions of pounds - the catch being thatthey fail, they die. Get the biggest news delivered to your inbox.for the Mirroraposs free newslettersWhile the far-fetched premise thankfully isnapost inspired by real le, a side plot sees workers for the aposgameapos dragging off injured participants to harvest their organs and sell them off. Just months before the showaposs release, UN human rights experts warned they were extremely alarmed by reports of alleged organ harvesting in real le. Minorities including followers of the religious movement Falun Gong, Uyghurs, Tibetans, Muslims and Christians are being targeted in detention in China, the reports claim. The UN experts say they have received credible information that detainees are being mysteriously subjected to blood tests and organ examinations such as ultrasound and x-rays - without consent. “Forced organ harvesting in China appears to be targeting specic ethnic, linguistic or religious minorities held in detention, often without being explained the reasons for arrest or given arrest warrants, at dferent locations,” they said. “We are deeply concerned by reports of discriminatory treatment of the prisoners or detainees based on their ethnicity and religion or belief. “According to the allegations received, the most common organs removed from the prisoners are reportedly hearts, kidneys, livers, corneas and, less commonly, parts of livers. This form of trafficking with a medical nature allegedly involves health sector professionals, including surgeons, anaesthetists and other medical specialists.”  China is facing a huge shortage of organs that can be used for transplants, but under controversial rules recipients can book surgeries for specic dates and locations. This doesnapost happen in other countriesapos systems, as surgeons cannot predict when a potential donor will die. Under Chinaaposs rules, the donoraposs organs will be sent to the most urgent patient on a waiting list who is within travelling distance. This has allowed the country to establish a horric aposkill to orderapos system, but despite widespread condemnation, Beijing has been able to cover it up by under-reporting transplant figures to the World Health Organisation.A recent statistical analysis of Chinaaposs current organ transplant system showed the numbers China has been putting out have been falsied, Susie Hughes, executive director of The International Coalition to End Transplant Abuse in China, told Daily Mail Australia.When you examine hospital revenues, bed utilisation rates and the number of surgical teams from the official Chinese data... the figure is more likely to be between , to , transplants per year. aposI became a robot... you carry out what you are programmed toapos China has persecuted a number of minority groups over the years, with thousands of Falun Gong detained as religious prisoners around the turn of the century. In , human rights lawyers began campaigning on the issue of organ harvesting, but  years later, little has been done to curb the sickening practice.  While the Falun Gong were once the target of the authorities, following its effective dissolution as a movement the Uighur - an ethnic group of Muslims now largely situated in the north-west of China - became the new scapegoat.Last year, the China Tribunal published a landmark  page report after  months of investigation into organ harvesting in the country. Dr Tothi - who now works as a London Uber driver - contributed to the enquiry, having been forced to remove a prisoners organs while working as a doctor in .I became a robot, the father-of-three told MirrorOnline. You carry out what you are programmed to do. When I cut through there was bleeding, which means the heart was still beating. I understood why. This man was shot to the right chest. They knocked him out but did not let him die immediately so I had time to remove the organs.  It was an easy and quick operation which took  to  minutes. Even less because it’s a destructive operation. The chief surgeon put the organs in a box and said aposnow you take your team back to hospital, and today nothing happenedapos. When Dr Tothi was made to carry out the brutal surgery, the Chinese Communist Party was concerned with the Falun Gong - a religious group that top brass considered to be a grave threat to their authority. The identity of the man he was forced to operate on, without anesthetic, remains a mystery to him. Prisoner x-rayed at horric concentration camp Tens of thousands of Falun Gong prisoners of conscience are thought to have been killed so that their organs could be sold in the lucrative black market.Among the lucky survivors was Jenner Zeng, who was saved from having her innards plundered by a chance admission to a prison guard. For  hours a day the mum-of-one was forced to stand in the sun and recite regulations at a prison camp in Beijing until she fainted, at which point a guard would shock her awake with an electric batton. Itaposs very sad, because we failed to stop them when they did this to Falun Gong, Ms Zeng toldof the state-run programme of forced organ harvesting. The western world funded this persecution by investing in China. Thenow has the power to expand this mass murder to Uighur and the people of Hong Kong. During her time in the camp Ms Zeng was taken to a medical facility where she had her eyes tested and her organs touched. She explained to the doctor that she had been infected with hepatitis C during a blood transfusion after giving birth, but had been cured of it in the process of practising Falun Gong. A month later she and several thousand inmates were taken in shackles in large buses with their windows blacked out to a hospital where they were x-rayed. At a smaller clinic back at the camp their blood was taken without explanation. It was only after her release that Ms Zeng learned that the authorities had been removing the organs of prisoners to be sold to wealthy and powerful people, from China and from overseas. Only at that stage, I realised what a narrow escape I had, she explained.  If I had not told the doctor I had had hepatitis C, I could have become a victim as well. From my first dayI had a strange feeling. Is this real  Have I been sent to the concentration camps in the history books  Could this be happening in the st century  We read about it in the history books but it doesnapost happen anymore. I had been transferred to the Nazi concentration camps. That kind of feeling haunted me for a long time. aposMy name is the butcher... itaposs like slaughtering pigsapos Also included in the  report is a transcript of a telephone call between an investigator and Zhu Jiabin, who admits to murdering and harvesting the organs of Gao Yixi in . Asked about the harvesting, Jiabin says: Sold them!’ After slaughtering and opening up the belly, you just carve out the organs and sell them. I only know to sell organs for money after organ harvesting. That is my principle... If you had guts to stand in front of me now I would live organ harvest you... My name is ‘the butcher’... I am called the butcher specialising in live organ harvesting... Itaposs nothing, just like slaughtering pigs. You come over to shave their hair first and then split open the belly. I would carve out whatever I need. After scooping the organs out, I would sell them.Last year, a group of doctors were found to have harvested the organs of car crash victims and then sold them for cash.Six people, including four doctors, were jailed in China having been caught up in the countryaposs thriving organ black market. It followed growing reports that the country was executing Muslim prisoners and taking their organs to treat patients dying of Covid-. Concerns were raised after Beijing boasted about a successful double transplant operation on a patient given just days to live. Human rights groups questioned how the -year-oldaposs two matched lungs were found in a matter of days.Got a story  Get in touch by emailing alex.bellotti@reachplcComment MORE ON Squid GameNetflixChinese Communist PartyFalun Gong" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: la palmas second lava river
story: La Palmas second lava river to hit ocean in hours as explosions predictedA second river of lava on La Palma has caused explosions and forced people to flee their houses and is expected to hit the ocean in hoursLava from the Cumbre Vieja volcano burns through a house Image: REUTERSByRita SobotKieren Williams:,  Oct | commentsLa Palma’s second red-hot river of lava is due to hit the ocean “within hours” with more explosions and evictions predicted ahead. A second “unstoppable” river of lava is burning its way through land and houses on the Canary Island of La Palma. Scientists have warned that this will “very likely” cause more explosions and gas clouds.Only an hour ago, the Canary Islands Volcano Institute published a terrying video on its Twitter site , showing the lava moving slowly and relentlessly forward.The tweet read: At : Canarian time lava flows keep moving unstoppable and the LP- over the remnants of the industrial park access.  The institute posted dramatic pictures of the volcanic eruption at night, saying: Breathtaking view of the eruption at : Canarian time in the vicinity of Tacande. It has been one month since the initial eruption in the Cumbre Vieja mountains. Since then, , buildings have been destroyed and  have been partially damaged or are in danger from the lava. Businesses and farms have also been affected as banana, vine and avocado crops have been wiped out.  Some of the plumes erupting from the volcanoes have reached as high as , metres. Around , people have been evacuated due to the ongoing lava flows. Involcan spokesman David Calvo said the eruption of the volcano was still very strong and the second river of lava would reach the sea this afternoon. Lava emitted last night had joined the river of lava and sped it up with it being only  metres from the clfs in Tazacorte a few hours ago.  Mr. Calvo said there would almost certainly be more evictions because of the potential danger. He also predicted the eruption would continue for some time as about , tons of sulfur dioxide were recorded on Monday, and for the eruption to begin to be dead,  tons or less must be registered. Last night, the Canary government said it was monitoring the situation, particularly with regard to further evictions. Due to unfavourable conditions effecting air quality, the population of El Paso has been advised to stay indoors where possible. Some areas were left without electricity because the magma flow has brought down power lines but emergency generators have now been brought in.  The whole of the island of La Palma is still registering underground quakes, the biggest of which has been . on the Richter scale. There is also a further warning that the operation of La Palma airport could be affected. In the meantime, arrangements are being made for the imminent rescue of up to six dogs trapped by the lava. Rescuers intend to use drones carrying wire baskets and are just waiting for permission to start. If successful, it would be the first rescue of its kind in the country. title: knights-cgi-work-community-based-initiatives
story: AFTER A long period of no competitive rugby, Southern Knights are thrilled to have reached the  final of the FOSROC Super Rugby League and are particularly grateful to main sponsor global IT and business consulting services company CGI for their support over the past two years.Rob Chrystie, Head coach at the Southern Knights, said: ldquoThe Southern Knights management and players have really enjoyed theirto rugby since the end of July.CGI, our headline sponsor have shown unwavering support to the Southern Knights throughout extremely challenging times. We are exceptionally grateful for their continued support and determined to repay that commitment on the pitch whist working closely with them in the wider Borders community.ldquoDuring lockdown we were able to continue to offer rugby activities for the younger children, and during April we were able to support a new Try It Out campaign aimed at children that wouldnrsquot typically have access to rugby or sporting activities because of social or economic barriers. We feel very strongly that the ability to pay shouldnrsquot prevent access to sport.ldquoParents and carers were offered the option to pay what they could, or in some cases nothing at all. Over  boys and girls joined in the fun sessions at the Melrose pitches, and the majority registered to stay on until the end of the summer season. The lting of restrictions has allowed the Southern Knights to launch their buddy scheme aligning some of their semi-professional players to the younger players to help encourage and develop their skills and to inspire children to play to the best of their ability.ldquoThis inclusive ethos is shared by CGI and the award winning Inspire Learning Programme developed in partnership with Scottish Borders Council for pupils from primary four to sixth year in high school throughout the area.ldquoThis uses iPads and an array of other tools to support learning and aims to benefit all children and teachers by raising attainment, support equity and inclusion, and to work towards preparing young people for a digital future. We are keen to continue to support these initiatives in conjunction with CGI over the coming months and years.Dominic Taddei, Chair of Southern Knights Super Board said: ldquoWe are delighted to continue to work a further term with our headline sponsor CGI. Their support through very dficult times has been phenomenal and we look forward to working with them as we get ready to approach the finals day, and to now have the ability to offer a wider audience for FOSROC Super with the fantastic news that was released by Scottish Rugby on rd June  that every Super Sunday fixture has been televised live on free-to-air television by new broadcast partner, FreeSports. The FOSROC Super finals weekend will take place on the weekend of    October, and we look forward to showcasing CGI as our headline sponsor at the finals event.The continuing partnership between CGI and the Southern Knights is not only a relationship supporting sport in the Scottish Borders but also Southern Knights players and coaches are working closely with CGI on community-based initiatives in Borders schools, delivering motivational and inspirational videos for the pupils. CGI employees will also benefit from the relationship with the option to join in fitness sessions at the Greenyards and receiving motivational and leadership messages from the coaches.

title: hawick-man-drove-almost-four-times-legal-alcohol-limit
story: A BORDERS man who drove while almost four times the legal alcohol limit has been banned from the road for two years.Fty-six-year-old Allan Knox, of Hawicks Twirlees Terrace, pleaded guilty to the offence which happened in Mart Street, Hawick, on March .Joanne Waller, prosecuting, told Jedburgh Sherf Court that two witnesses saw the accused in Morrisons car park walking towards them in possession of a bottle of wine.They thought he appeared unsteady on his feet and askedhe was drunk or unwell but he replied he was depressed and was slurring his words.He then drove off in towards Linden Crescent and was followed by the witnesses.Ms Waller said Knox ed to the car park and was found by the police asleep in his vehicle with the keys in the ignition.He was arrested and taken to Hawick Police Station where he was cautioned and charged .Knox initially told officers he had not been driven but had earlier gone to Morrisons for a bottle of wine.He pleaded guilty to a charge of driving with a breath alcohol count of  microgrammes ndash the legal limit being .Defence lawyer Ross Dow said his client had been struggling with depression following the end of his -year marriage.Sherf Valerie Johnston noted a previous conviction for drink driving and said as a result the minimumof ban was two years.In addition he was fined pound, reduced from pound due to the guilty plea, and a pound Victim Surcharge was imposed.

title: first-class-stamp-honours-first-class-player
story: BORDERS rugby legend Roy Laidlaw is to feature in a new set of stamps issued by the Royal Mail.The eight stamps in the set mark the th anniversary of the first international rugby match, staged between Scotland and England at Raeburn Place in Edinburgh in .Scrum-half Laidlaw, whose two first-half tries against Ireland at Lansdowne Road in Dublin, in , were instrumental in Scotland winning their first Triple Crown since , will feature.The former Jed-Forest star, who was capped -times for his country, recounted: ldquoI remember Ireland won the toss and decided to play against the wind in the first-half. I scored early off a lineout, then we got a penalty try at a scrum and then I got over in the corner off a scrum.ldquoI think Irsquod scored in the same corner a few years before playing for Scotland B.Due to injury, Laidlaw didnrsquotfor the second-half. ldquoBut we played some great rugby then. Keith Robertson scored a try and Peter Dods scored in the corner from a typically unselfish pass from Roger Baird.Laidlaw, who had captained Scotland and also toured New Zealand with the British  Irish Lions in , was in hospital as the celebrations at Scotlandrsquos - win continued into the night.He recovered to take his place against France at home a fortnight later when Scotland won their first Grand Slam in  years.He added: ldquoThat was just such an achievement. I mean, it was our first since . But while some of the boys were still partying, I was back at work the following Monday rewiring the public toilets in Jedburgh.ldquoI owed so much to my granny, Peggy Walker. She had introduced me to rugby when I was a kid. She saw the  Grand Slam in person the  Grand Slam in person and she watched the  Grand Slam on the telly. She lived to the grand old age of .ldquoSo, being on the stamp  Well, Irsquoll just say thanks to my granny Peggy, because it all wouldnrsquot have happened without her enthusiasm. She was rugby daft.The full set of stamps features: JPR Williams Emily Scarratt Danielle Waterman Sophie Spence Roy Laidlaw Kim Littlejohn Simon Geoghegan Melissa Berry and Jonny Wilkinson.They will go on sale from October .

story: TWO estatesin the Borders will be joining the dozens across the countryuntil December to celebrate the importance of trees to our lives and our landscape during the Scottish Tree Festival.The estates will be inviting visitors to explore some of the finest tree collections and to enjoy the spectacle as the canopy changes from green to gold and scarlet.At Cringletie near Peebles guests are being invited to walk amongst the woods and then enjoy afternoon tea in front of a blazing log fire while at Abbotsford near Melrose, the guided tours that are taking place during the Festival will include a chance to stroll amongst he woods that were planted by Sir Walter Scott himself.Dozens of gardens and estates, from Wester Ross to the Borders, are taking part in the Festival including Armadale Castle on Skye, Blair Atholl in Perthshire and Ardkinglas in Argyll where visitors can see some of Scotlands Champion trees - the biggest and broadest of their kind in the country.These and the many other events that will be taking part have been organised by Discover Scottish Gardens, which represents gardens and nurseries across the country.Joanna Macpherson, director, DSG, said: ldquoAgainst the backdrop of COP taking place in Glasgow, trees have never been more important and Scotland not only has a unique legacy of historic trees, but through careful conservation and replanting, this countryrsquos tree cover is increasing once again.ldquoThe Festival allows us to celebrate the place of trees in our lives, to enjoy their beauty and to explore how we can make more of them in our own gardens."

title: music-streaming-market-facing-competition-inquiry
story: The UKrsquos competition watchdog is to launch an inquiry into the music streaming market and whether it is competitive and fair.The Competition and Markets Authorityhas confirmed it plans to begin a market study into the sector amid concerns over the rise of streaming as the dominant force in the industry and its impact on artists and music listeners.The CMA market study will be a fact-finding investigation to identy and consider how best to tackle any competition and consumer issues uncovered.# Wersquove announced our intention to launch a market study into #musicstreaming.Wersquove written to the government and @CommonsDCMSSelect Committee to outline our next steps. pic XkqwwyCbmdash Competition  Markets AuthorityOctober , CMA chief executive Andrea Coscelli said: ldquoThe UK has a love affair with music and is home to many of the worldrsquos most popular artists. We want to do everything we can to ensure that this sector is competitive, thriving and works in the interests of music lovers.ldquoOver the past decade, the music industry has evolved almost beyond recognition, with streaming now accounting for more than % of all music listened to in this country.ldquoA market study will help us to understand these radical changes and build a view as to whether competition in this sector is working well or whether further action needs to be taken.Last month, the Government referred the issue to the CMA following recommendations from MPs on the Digital, Culture, Media and SportCommittee in the wake of its inquiry into music streaming.In its report on the economics of streaming, it warned that ldquopitul s from the current system are affecting the ldquoentire creative ecosystem, and also raised ldquodeep concerns about the position of the major music companies in the market.In response, the CMA has now said it will prioritise the launching of its market study in light of the concerns expressed by MPs and their report.DCMS Committee chairman Julian Knight said: ldquoWe welcome the decision by the CMA to urgently carry out a competition inquiry into music streaming and the dominance of the major music groups.ldquoThat the CMA has made this a priority is a big result for the DCMS Committee, endorsing one of the key recommendations of our inquiry into music streaming.ldquoOur investigation exposed fundamental problems within the structure of the music industry itself. title: pps-defends-decision-bring-dennis-hutchings-trial
story: Northern Irelandrsquos Public Prosecution Service has defended the decision to prosecute Army veteran Dennis Hutchings over a Troubles shooting.Hutchings died in hospital in Belfast on Monday after contracting Covid-, leading unionist politicians to raise concerns that the case against him had been allowed to proceed.DUP leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson challenged the prosecution service over what new and compelling evidence led to the trial.Deputy Director of Public Prosecutions Michael Agnew said: ldquoThe PPS decision to prosecute Mr Hutchings for attempted murder was taken after an impartial and independent application of the Test for Prosecution.ldquoThe Test for Prosecution requires a consideration of whether the available evidence provides a reasonable prospect of conviction and,it does, whether prosecution is in the public interest.ldquoWhilst a review of a previous no prosecution decision does not require the existence of new evidence, the police investigation in this case resulted in a file being submitted to the PPS which included certain evidence not previously available.ldquoIn the course of the proceedings there were rulings by High Court judges that the evidence was sufficient to put Mr Hutchings on trial and also that the proceedings were not an abuse of process.Mr Agnew said the PPS recognised the ldquoconcerns in some quarters in relation to the decision to bring the prosecution.He added: ldquoWe would like to offer our deepest sympathies to the family and friends of Mr Hutchings, and acknowledge their painful loss.ldquoHowever, where a charge is as serious as attempted murder, it will generally be in the public interest to prosecute.ldquoOur thoughts are also with the family of John Pat Cunningham who have waited for many decades in the hope of seeing due process take its course.Eighty-year-old Hutchings had been suffering from kidney disease and the court had been sitting only three days a week to enable him to undergo dialysis treatment between hearings.He was charged with the attempted murder of John Pat Cunningham in Co Tyrone in .vw,vw,px, px"John Pat Cunningham The former member of the Le Guards regiment, from Cawsand in Cornwall, had denied a count of attempted grievous bodily harm with intent.Mr Cunningham, , was shot dead as he ran away from an Army patrol across a field near Benburb.People who knew him said he had the mental age of a child and was known to have a deep fear of soldiers.His family have responded to the death of Hutchings saying they wished to acknowledge that this is a dficult time for the family, adding that they should be given time to grieve.ldquoWhen the time is judged appropriate, the family will respond in more detail to the issues surrounding the prosecution of Dennis Hutchings, they said.Meanwhile former veterans minister Johnny Mercer tweeted that he is ldquodevastated by the death of my dear friend.pic zKzVVBOADBmdash Johnny MercerOctober , Mr Mercer, who accompanied Hutchings to court on several days of the trial, said he ldquoremains fiercely proud of him.Hutchings died at the Mater Hospital on Monday while in Belfast for the trial.Hours earlier, the trial had been adjourned for three weeks in light of Hutchingsrsquo health.Sir Jeffrey said there are ldquoserious questions that need to be answered.ldquoWhat was the compelling new evidence that had emerged, given that Dennis had previously faced two investigations and had been found guilty of no crime, and therefore why now  he told PA in London.ldquoWhat was in the public interest to bring this man to trial at this time, particularly in relation to his ill-health and the fact that I doubtthere was new and compelling evidence in this case Sir Jeffrey added: ldquoI think that we have to have a fair system. Everyone is equal under the law and equally subject to the law.ldquoThat means that we have a process that examines all the cases where families have an interest in pursuing justice andafter investigation there is new and compelling evidence that could lead to a prosecution, then I think the PPS and the courts should look at those cases.vw,vw,px, px"DUP leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson Downing Street said the ldquotragic case illustrated the problems of pursuing historical allegations through the courts.The Prime Ministerrsquos official spokesman said: ldquoOur sincere condolences go to the family, friends and loved ones of Dennis Hutchings.ldquoThe Ministry of Defence supported Mr Hutchings throughout his trial with legal representation and pastoral care, and that will continue to be offered to his family.The spokesman said ldquoitrsquos not for me to comment on the court proceedings, but added: ldquoThis tragic case highlights that the criminal justice approach broadly is no longer working and that is why we are committed to introducing new legislation to bring greater certainty for all communities, including the veterans and families of victims.In July, the Government announced plans for a statute of limitations that would end all prosecutions for Troubles incidents up to April .The death of Hutchings was raised by Ulster Unionist Party leader Doug Beattie as a matter of the day in the Northern Ireland Assembly on Tuesday.Mr Beattie extended his condolences to the families of Hutchings as well as John Pat Cunningham.Hetold MLAs that just as the family of Mr Cunningham deserves truth and justice, so does the Hutchings family.ldquoPeople need to understand or find out why his case was elevated above all other cases, why his case suddenly ended up at the top of the pile hellip and this goes to the heart of some of the issues that we are having to deal with in what is a dficult legacy process which is affecting our present here now, he said.ldquoThat is something we do have to look into, it is something that we do need to examine, to be fair to the family, to understand why this was elevated, we need to understand what was the new evidence which elevated this case and we do need to find out what was in the public interest to bring this case forward.Sinn Fein MLA Linda Dillon described the death of Hutchings as a ldquohuman tragedy.However, she cautioned those criticising the PPS for bringing the case to trial, telling MLAs they are legislators and should not interfere in the judicial process.ldquoThis was a judicial process, it is not for us to interfere in that, she told MLAs..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: PPS defends decision to bring Dennis Hutchings to trial

title: net-zero-matter
story: The UK has a target to reach net zero emissions by  and the Government has set out its strategy for how it aims to get there.But what is ldquonet zero and why does it matter Greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, such as carbon dioxide, trap heat and keep the planet warm.But the more of these gases we have put into the atmosphere through activities such as burning fossil fuels to heat homes, drive cars and provide electricity for our lives, the more the planet warms.These rising temperatures drive climate change, the extreme weather, rising sea levels, heatwaves, and floods that we are already seeing increase around us.So, just as you need to turn off a tap completely to stop the level of water in a bath from continuing to rise, we need to cut emissions to zero to stop the greenhouse gas levels, and therefore temperatures, rising more to prevent more dangerous climate change.Completely stopping emissions is extremely dficult, but there are some measures, such as planting trees, which can absorb greenhouse gases from the atmosphere, the equivalent of bailing some water out of the bath to keep the water level steady eventhe tap is still running slightly.vw,vw,px, px"Global warming and the greenhouse effect So emissions have to be cut as much as possible, and any remaining pollution, from hard-to-tackle sectors such as aviation, needs to be ldquooffset by action that absorbs carbon to have the net effect of cutting emissions to zero.To stabilise global temperature at any level, emissions must reach this ldquonet zero point eventually.Scientists say that to limit temperature rises to .C above pre-industrial levels, beyond which increasingly dangerous climate impacts will be felt, global carbon emissions must be brought down to net zero by around  with deep cuts to other greenhouse gases.And the UNrsquos Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Changehas concluded that signicant amounts of carbon dioxide removal will not just be needed for mopping up residual emissions, but for creating negative levels of emissions to bring down temperatures again after overshooting the .C level.In the UK, the Government legislated in June  that the UK must reach net zero greenhouse gas emissions by , by mandating a % cut in emissions by that date.That requires deep cuts in emissions and therefore changes in all sectors, including how we heat our homes, how we travel, our power sector, how industry uses energy and even our diets, and efforts to capture some emissions.vw,vw,px, px"How landscapes can catch carbon The statutory advisory Climate Change Committeehas said it expects more than  million tonnes of emissions will be captured in  to offset the pollution the UK is still putting out then.Ways to do that include burning plant matter for energy and capturing and burying the carbon emissions, known as BECCS, technology that captures carbon dioxide directly from the air, expanding woodlands and restoring peatlands.Delivering net zero is not without controversy, with concerns raised about the cost.But the CCC has concluded it would cost less than % of GDP through the next  years to deliver, and would bring benefits such as cleaner air, better health and provide a jobs boost, though there is a need to ensure the costs are spread fairly.It is also controversial because some environmentalists are concerned some companies and governments think they can continue to pollute while ldquooffsetting themselves out of the crisis, instead of tackling the emissions at source.However, the CCCrsquos chief executive Chris Stark has said setting a net zero target is the right approach, and the goal has galvanised action.He said it was dferent from the UKrsquos old target of % emissions cut by  because there was no longer a % of residual pollution that organisations or sectors thought they could emit.ldquoI see real progress having set net zero as a goal, not just in government circles and in policy, but crucially in the commercial sector, he said..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Net zero: what is it and why does it matter

title: officials-keeping-close-eye-new-mutation-delta-variant
story: The Government is keeping a ldquoclose eye on a descendant of the coronavirus Delta iant that is being seen in a growing number of cases.Downing Street said it was monitoring the AY. iant, but insisted there was no evidence it spreads more easily.The Prime Ministerrsquos official spokesman said: ldquoItrsquos something wersquore keeping a very close eye on.ldquoTherersquos no evidence to suggest that this iant hellip the AY. one hellip is more easily spread.ldquoTherersquos no evidence for that, but as you would expect wersquore monitoring it closely and wonrsquot hesitate to take actionnecessary.vw,vw,px, px"Scientists say AY. carries two characteristic mutations in the spike, YH and AV, both of which have been found in ious other coronavirus lineages since the beginning of the pandemic.However, they have remained at low frequency until now.The first strains carrying both mutations were sequenced in April , and either are found in any iant of concern.Francois Balloux, professor of computational systems biology at University College London and director of the UCL Genetics Institute, said: ldquoThe AV was found in the B.. lineage that swept Europe in the summer of , but careful follow-up analyses pointed to the lineage likely having no inherent transmissibility advantage and that its spread was most likely caused by demographic processes.He added that neither mutation was an obvious candidate for increased transmissibility, but that mutations can have dferent, sometimes unexpected, effects in dferent strains.Prof Balloux explained: ldquoAs AY.. is still at fairly low frequency, a % increase in its transmissibility could have caused only a small number of additional cases.ldquoAs such it hasnrsquot been driving the recent increase in case numbers in the UK.He said the emergence of another more transmissible strain would be ldquosuboptimal, adding: ldquoThis is not a situation comparable to the emergence of Alpha and Delta that were far more transmissiblethan any strain in circulation at the time.ldquoHere we are dealing with a potential small increase in transmissibility that would not have a comparable impact on the pandemic.AY. is rare outside the UK, and there have been only three cases detected in the US so far.In Denmark, the other country that, besides the UK, has excellent genomic surveillance in place, it reached a % frequency but has gone down since.Work is under way to test whether it may be less well recognised by antibodies..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Officials keeping title: halloween-guising-scotland-meaning-different-trick-treating
story: With Halloween just around the corner, the word guising is popping up more and more frequently.But did you know the term is unique to Scotlandand Ireland Heres everything you need to know about the Scots term guising, how it dfers from trick or treating and other Scottish Halloween traditions.What does guising mean Guising derives from the word disguise, and is based on the notion that people dress up at Halloween.Children dress up and go from house to house, telling jokes and stories or singing songs in exchange for sweeties and food.The Collins dictionary defines guising as "the practice orcustomofdisguisingoneself infancydress, often with amask, andvisitingpeoples houses, especially atHalloween".According to folklore, children dressed up so they could venture out safely without wicked ghouls detecting them.Homeowners may leave pumpkins or decorations outside their houses to indicate they are welcoming guisers.Is guising dferent to trick or treating Yes, guising is dferent to trick or treating.Traditionally, guising requires you to tell a story or a joke or sing a song, while trick or treating simply requires going up to doors and calling "trick or treat".Treat usually refers to a sweetie or food item, while trick refers to thethreat ofa trick being played on homeownersthey dont offer a treat.What other Scottish Halloween traditions take place There are a few moreScottish Halloween traditions aside form guising.Before pumpkin carving became the done thing, Scots traditionally carved turnips instead and filled them with candles.Apple dookin is also a Scottish tradition people have to get apples out of a basin of water using just their mouths.Alternatively, people hold forks in their mouths and drop them from a distance in an attempt to stab an apple.Another tradition was especially for newly engaged couples the couple would each burn a nut on the fire andthe nuts burned quietly a happy union lay ahead, whilethey crackled and hissed there was more likely a turbulent future.A game that has been modernised is treacle scones - back in the day, people used to try to eat scones suspended with strings without using their hands.Nowadays, this game tends to be played using donuts.

title: black-friday-2021-black-friday-year-uk---date-time

It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. title: trusts-30-000-gift-keeps-seabird-centre-afloat-post-covid
story: The trust awarded the charity pound, towards its conservation and education efforts.The award recognises the contribution the charity makes to the local community through conservation volunteering projects which both improve the quality of the local environment and help people understand more about the wildle along the East Lothian coastline.Olwyn Owen, chair of North Berwick Trustrsquos grants group, said: ldquoNorth Berwick Trust is delighted to be able to support the Scottish Seabird Centre with a one-off grant to help it recover from the financial impact of the pandemic.ldquoThe Seabird Centre is a signicant local charity and brings many benefits to the North Berwick community, as well as playing an important role in national efforts to conserve and raise awareness of our wonderful marine le.The Scottish Seabird CentreSusan Davies, chief executive of the Scottish Seabird Centre, said: ldquoWe are extremely grateful to North Berwick Trust for this generous grant award.ldquoThe development of the Scottish Seabird Centre,  years ago, was supported by the local community and it is great to see that it is still valued within the community.ldquoThe award gives us a further boost whilst we continue to chart our way through the financial impacts of Covid-, which saw our centrersquos doors closed and the loss of the main income that funded many of our charitable activities.ldquoIt signals confidence in the steps wersquove been taking to rebuild partnerships within the community and to broaden the range of conservation and education activities that we provide.ldquoOur visitor experience doors have now fully reopened and we look forward to welcoming people from the town to the centre and to join in with our regular programmes of events and activities.The Scottish Seabird Centre runs programmes of learning and activities that promote the positive links between nature and peoplersquos wellbeing.They are designed to be accessible to all within the local community.

title: tims-tales-embraced-primeval-forest
story: Itrsquos not really a forest, of course, but a very small strip of ancient woodland, east of Innerwick, that clings to the steep slopes of the glen by Crowhill. The woodland is a nature reserve currently managed by the Scottish Wildle Trust.The upper path takes you to Innerwick Castle. This path is narrow in places, although quite well trodden so easy to follow.But it is sided by a steep decline into the gorge that demands you take care when walking. The castle, built in the th century, is perched dramatically atop a sandstone outcrop looking over the glen. It is picturesque now but a crumbling ruin in such a precarious condition that itrsquos not recommended to venture inside.I wrote of its history on this page over seven years ago, and will touch on it again here, but the purpose of this visit was mainly to explore the gorge below the castle, which Irsquod never managed to do.Irsquoll give a warning here too: the lower path that takes you closer to the burn, although marked, doesnrsquot seem to be maintained and is in parts very muddy and slippery. It can become an adventure rather than a woodland walk. But thatrsquos what we wanted.We were immersed in native woodland as we descended, embraced by ash and oak trees. The burn ran with some confidence through the glen, carrying the rainfall of previous days. Touches of autumn were everywhere, yet the summer canopy was still intact. It was a perfect combination.As the path heads deeper up the glen, the trunk of a massive fallen tree make it an obstacle course, but also an opportunity to sit and just take in the beauty of the place and soak up the birdsong.In those moments, it was possible to forget that we were, in fact, in a landscape dominated by agriculture and open fields. The steep sides of the gorge hide the fact that the wood is just a very narrow strip. The eye is deceived, the imagination lit and the senses lted.I was determined to make it to the water. The short scramble down to the burn from the path was a drama of mud.I know, Irsquom not selling this place so well, am I, but it was the challenge to reach the burn that made it feel so remote and wild once we got there.Then one of my kids, in between complaining about muddy shoes, said something that lit up the day for me.ldquoWow, you know, it almost feels like we are in a world of fairytale make believe, you know because we are in a wood that feels like itrsquos mysterious and magical at the same time.She summed up my feelings as I sat by the burn, listening to the water tumble over the rocks.I really wanted to walk up the burn to the point below the castle.Wersquod earlier peered down at the burn from the base of the rock on which the castle is built at least a ft-fall, I reckoned.It was far too dangerous to descend at that point, although I had wanted to it was where a Scots soldier from the castle leapt for his le in  when the castle was besieged by English hakbutters, an early kind of musketeer.He was desperate his comrades had been picked off by the gunfire, so he took the chance to escape.Miraculously, he survived the initial fall and was allowed to run to safety. Sadly, he made the fatal decision to run upstream, towards Thornton Castle, where he was seen and shot by a dferent group of English soldiers who knew nothing of his daring feat.The incident was recorded by an English eyewitness, but we have no name for the man who met his end so tragically in this gorge ndash just another nameless victim of a brutal war that became known later as the lsquoRough Wooingrsquo.Later, the castle was used as a base by moss troopers in  in their attacks on Cromwellrsquos supply route, but thatrsquos another story.The melancholy of the glenrsquos history didnrsquot diminish its beauty for me and I made my way carefully along the burn, jumping from stone to stone, getting my boots muddy and soaked in the process. It really was a magical experience in which my inner child felt free.However, I had a dferent kind of gunfire to contend with as I ventured upstream. Irsquod insisted my kids stay in a safer place and my we Kate was happy to be with them and keep her feet dry. But the children showered me with a volley of distant shouts and yells that they wanted to come too, which I felt would have been too hazardous for the youngest.So I was compelled to abandon my exploration in case they broke ranks you see, they donrsquot always do as they are told, especially when their dad is doing something they want to experience as well!But I will I can find the time in the winter, with perhaps just one of the kids: my own inner child.

title: gas-works-see-road-closures-prestonpans-13-weeks
story: SGN announced that it would begin work to upgrade its gas network in the Prestonpans area on Monday.The work involves replacing ,m of old metal gas mains and service pipes with new plastic pipe, ensuring a continued safe and reliable gas supply to the local community.SGN has planned its work in close consultation with local authorities to reduce disruption as much as possible.The project will be carried out by SGN contractor George Ritchie  Son.During the works, parking restrictions will be in operation allowing safe access to the pipe ndash some road closures will also be required.Temporary traffic signals will be in operation at certain times, which may cause delays during peak periods.Emergency vehicle access will be maintained throughout the work.The gas work will be suspended during the Christmas holidays, with operatives ing early in the new year.Road closures include Prestongrange Terracersquos junction with Prestongrange Road, and Polwarth Terracersquos junction with Gardiner Terrace.To minimise disruption, SGN work will be carried out on a phased basis and not all streets will be affected at the same time.Access to driveways and garages will be maintained unless previously agreed with the occupier.An SGN spokesperson said: ldquoWersquoll be working as quickly as possible to complete our work and will be making every effort to minimise inconvenience to the local community.Suspension of parking is as follows:Prestonpans Community Council is calling for greater clarity on road works in and around the town, ideally in the form of an interactive map showing all the restrictions over time.A spokesperson for the community council said: ldquoInidual roadworks are obviously necessary for the maintenance of our public utilities.ldquoHowever, there is a balance to be struck between maintenance and what can quickly become a public nuisance.ldquoIf roadworks are all planned to minimise distribution, there is currently no way of telling. For example, Blindwells seems to open and close our key access road to the A on a whim.ldquoWith all the building works going on, there needs to be much tighter management, notication and planning.ldquoDevelopers should also be held to schedule and asked to contribute to the local community for unnecessary job overruns and traffic delays.ldquoOne key concern, for example, is the timing of sequencing on temporary lights.ldquoSequence settings can have a huge impact on road users.ldquoThese lights should be independently assessedleft in place longer than a day.ldquoThis is the information technology age letrsquos start using it to manage and monitor our service providers.SGN said it would be writing to residents and other local stakeholders to make them aware of the project.Residents with enquiries about the project can call SGN on   .

title: day-activities-dunbar-start-pilgrims-walk-cop26-climate-conference
story: Walkers will follow the John Muir Way from Dunbar to Glasgow for the COP climate conference.Ahead of setting off from John Muirrsquos Birthplace, on Dunbarrsquos High Street, a number of family friendly events are taking place in the townrsquos Lauderdale Park.North Light Arts, Sustaining Dunbar and Friends of John Muirrsquos Birthplace are working to put together the special day on Sunday.It is hoped the day will bring together free activities that highlight environmental messages surrounding the ongoing climate emergency, the importance of the human relationship to the earthrsquos soils and nature, a celebration of the pilgrims and the experience of contemplative walking with a special purpose.The events get under way at pm and feature Rowanbank Environmental Arts, a printing workshop by Rebellious Threads, bike-powered flour milling with Shed Therapy, storytelling with the Courierrsquos Tim Porteus and pizza-making with Muddy Buddies.St Annersquos Church will display Stitches for Survival craftivism banners, and offer space for creative prayer, reflection and guided meditations.A led sensory slow walk will begin from John Muirrsquos Birthplace at pm to the harbour, where music and readings will take place within the Battery from .pm.The Battery performance programme includes poetry by Rita Bradd, readings by the Battery Theatre, a special performance by Dunbar Voices of Enough Is Enough, a song written by Oi Musica and Karine Polwart for COP, and a unique Keeper of the Soils ceremony.The day will be rounded off at Belhaven Church Hall with a pilgrimsrsquo supper and a thought-provoking talk by Alastair McIntosh.The pilgrims will set off the following day and make their way to Glasgow in time for the conference, which begins at the end of the month.

title: scotland-cricketers-play-icc-mens-t20-world-cup-kit-designed-haddington-schoolgirl
story: The ICC Menrsquos T World Cup gets under way in the United Arab Emirates and Oman this weekend.Scotland, who start their tournament against Bangladesh this Sunday, will be wearing a design created by Haddingtonrsquos Rebecca Downie.The youngsterrsquos pattern was chosen from more than  entries from schoolchildren across Scotland. The shirt, based on the colours of Scotlandrsquos national emblem the thistle, was selected unanimously by the team.Rebecca, , saw her design made real when she and her family were special guests of the Scotland team at the recent T International against Zimbabwe in Edinburgh.The new secondary school pupil met the players, who narrowly lost out on the day, and was presented with the first shirt off the production line.A keen cricketer and Scotland fan, she cannot wait to see the team wearing her design.The all rounder said: ldquoI was so excited when I heard I had won the competition, I couldnrsquot believe it.ldquoI was so happy to see the shirt in real le, it looks brilliant!ldquoIt was amazing to meet the team and watch them play against Zimbabwe.ldquoI will be wearing my shirt and cheering them on in every game in the World Cup.Rebeccarsquos mum, Anne, said the family were counting down to the tournament getting under way.She said: ldquoShe will be really thrilled to see them all wearing it and we will be crowding round the TV screen to watch it.Kyle Coetzer , who captains the Scotland team, was delighted to meet the youngster.Kyle said: ldquoIt was great to meet Rebecca and her family recently and see her wearing the new shirt.ldquoThe team are really proud of the design and we are planning to go out there and do it justice with our performances in the World Cup.ldquoWe hope that the fans will enjoy the new design and wear them proudly as they support us from back home.Replica shirts can be bought from Cricket Scotlandrsquos clothing partner, Gray-Nicolls.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-october-11-15-1996-1971-1921
story: years ago...GOLFERS were fearful children were being put at risk, reported the East Lothian Courier on October , .Furious golfers claim childrenrsquos lives are being threatened when they walk through Winterfield Golf Course to study nearby rock pools.And they also accuse East Lothian Council of ldquosheer bloody-mindedness in failing to deal with the problem swtly.Members at the coastal Winterfield Golf Course, on North Road, Dunbar, regularly have to halt their rounds to avoid hitting schoolchildren wandering on to the greens and fairways on their way to the shore.Mr Michael OrsquoDonnell, secretary of Winterfield Golf Club, said: ldquoOur concern is that a child is definitely going to be killed or injured.ldquoA golf ball striking a child at over  miles per hour could easily kill them.A golfer from Newtongrange, Midlothian, Mr William Conlon, wrote a letter to the club after a dangerous incident in September....and  years agoDISCUSSIONS about demolishing a gun shed in Dunbar were highlighted in The Haddingtonshire Courier on October  .The future of the gun shed at the former Castlepark Barracks at Dunbar is to be discussed again by the County Planning Committee.The matter was raised at the meeting of the County Council on Monday by Councillor Mrs F. E. Smeed, Dunbar, who said the Town Council had understood the shed was going to be demolished but the Planning Committee was recommending that it should be retained in the meantime and advertised for letting for the storage of caravans.She reminded members that the Castlepark site was the most valuable in Dunbar and said that at the moment it was an eyesore and more like a slum area....and  years agoTHREE boys appeared in court over stolen apples, told The Haddingtonshire Courier on October , .Three little boys from Pencaitland appeared before Sherf Macleod, at Haddington, on Monday and admitted having stolen three lbs of apples from the gardens attached to the Established Church manse there.The Fiscal explained that on the evening in question, the police constable at Pencaitland heard some boys in the garden and he was able to secure one of them.While the constable was speaking to a gentleman on the road, another boy dropped over the wall.One of the mothers, who accompanied her son to court, said she thought that after the fright the boys had received that she would have heard no more about the matter.

title: man-admits-shouting-swearing-partner
story: Callum Sinclair, of The Inveresk Estate, shouted, swore and adopted an aggressive manner during the incident.Sinclair also uttered offensive remarks and struck a door at an address at Seggarsdean Crescent in Haddington on July .Sinclair, , pleaded guilty to the amended offence during an appearance at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Thursday.He also admitted breaching bail conditions which had been imposed at the court on August  not to contact or approach the woman.Sinclair breached the order by being caught in her company on August .Sherf Roderick Flinn ordered Sinclair to be placed on a -month supervision order.The sherf deferred sentence on the breach matter to run alongside reviews of the community payback order, with the first being held in December.

title: knox-academy-school-bells-reduced-new-plans
story: Pupils and staff at the Haddington secondary school are being surveyed about the potential reduction in school bells.An assembly took place on the topic, with a consultation on the issue finishing last Wednesday.Sue Cook, Knox Academy headteacher, said: ldquoSchool bells were put into place in schools around  years ago and schooling has changed a great deal since this time.ldquoA number of schools have moved to no bells minimal bells to allow better time management , reduction in corridor movement via mass exits from classrooms on the sounding of the bell, and to reduce anxiety the sound of the bell causes for many young people with additional support needs.If the schoolrsquos plans are approved, the bells would be limited to the start of the day, end of break lunch and end of the day.The matter would be reviewed at the end of a month-long trial.

title: free-beauty-treatment-year-honour-bobbi
story: Shannon Godsell, , lives on John Crescent and has been working as a self-employed beauty therapist for eight years at The Joys Semi Permanent Lashes and Brows.The fully qualied eyelash technician and beauty therapist is offering a yearrsquos worth of free treatments for one winner to raise money to purchase a thermal drone which would search for lost dogs in East Lothian.Shannonrsquos raffle is in honour of her beloved late dog Bobbi ndash her best friend.Bobbi was a mixed terrier cross and was only a month away from her th birthday when she passed away unexpectedly.Shannon said that her dog took ill late at night in July and was rushed to the out-of-hours emergency vet, where tests showed she had advanced cancer and there was nothing that could be done.Shannon and her beloved dog BobbiShe was offered the option of having Bobbi put to sleep but decided to take her home to say goodbye to her family and children ndash Bobbi passed away in bed with Shannon early the following morning, before her family had a chance to say goodbye.She said: ldquoIt was all extremely fast, thankfully, because I wouldnrsquot have coped knowing she was ill and not being able to do anything to help her.ldquoIrsquom still really struggling with her passing, itrsquos not getting any easier. Shersquod been with me since I was  and Irsquom still beyond heartbroken.ldquoRaising this money to help others means so much to us having gone through so much worry over the years every time she ran away from her dog walkers or managed to escape from the house windows in her true Houdini style.ldquoIt will come as some form of comfort knowing that her drone ndash which will be named after her ndash will now be able to help others from her up in the sky.ldquoDrone SAR are the best team ever and bring so much comfort in the most frightening times.Bobbi has inspired Shannon to raise funds for a missing dog drone in East Lothian Shannon explained that Bobbi often escaped from the house and the Drone SAR Lost Dogs UK team helped by sending out ground-workers who lived nearby to help look for her.She added: ldquoThe last time she was gone overnight, and the time before, it was two days before we found her.ldquoA thermal drone would have helped dramatically but unfortunately there isnrsquot one manned here in East Lothian yet that could have been sent out.Last year, Shannon raised pound, for a drone but it was not enough to buy one outright, so the money was put towards a drone in another area of the UK.Now she is hoping to raise the full amount ndash more than pound, ndash to have one in the county.She has raised pound, so far.The winner of Shannonrsquos raffle can choose between regular semi-permanent eyelash treatment alongside a brow wax and tint or regular gel nails every two weeks with a brow wax and tint.The winner will be announced by the end of the month, with the free treatments beginning in November.Shannon added: ldquoIf anyone would like to offer to become a ground searcher, message their [Facebook] page with your postcode so you can be alerteda dog goes missing close by.Raffle numbers are pound each and can be bought by visiting www.facebook thejoyssemipermanentlashes

title: letter-week-toasting-12-years-enjoyleisure
story: enjoyleisure officially launched as a charitable leisure trust on October , , to provide and develop sport, leisure and recreational facilities and services for the benefit of the communities and visitors to East Lothian, on behalf of East Lothian Council. On launch day, the air was filled with anticipation, excitement, expectation and a little trepidation.Nevertheless, since its inception, it has grown from strength to strength. Over the last decade, enjoyleisure, its services, public activity offering, partnerships and overall investment in East Lothian has grown exponentially and energetically. We are additionally incredibly proud to be one of the countyrsquos largest employers, providing career opportunities for over  people across our communities.Aubigny Sports CentreAs a Scottish registered charity, enjoy is a not-for-profit organisation. Our aim is to provide affordable, accessible, best-value and safe facilities in all areas in which we operate. enjoy reinvests every penny and all surpluses back into our local communities to make East Lothian a better, healthier and enjoyable place to live and visit.Over the last  years, enjoyleisure, in conjunction with partners East Lothian Council, has enabled residents and its visitors to benefit from such initiatives as:Dunbar Leisure Pool. Picture: Google Mapsl The creation and installation of an East Lothian dedicated track and field athletics arenal Circa. pound. million investment upgrading Dunbar Leisure Pool to expand its lespan by -plus yearsl The development and upkeep of community-based G and G pitchesat Forester Park, Tranent Middleshot Park, Prestonpans and Pinkie St Peterrsquos, Musselburghl Opening of Ormiston Park pavilionl Building of the Stables Pavilion, providing a dedicated starters office and changing provision at Musselburgh Links, The Old Golf Coursel Repeated Bodyworks Gym refurbishments and equipment upgradesl The development of a thriving, award-winning Learn to Swim programmel Dramatic expansion of East Lothianrsquos fitness class offeringl Greatly valued and cost-saving membership schemesl Considerable investment and maintenance of venues, swimming pools and outdoor facilities themselves to secure longevity and ability to provide a sports and leisure provision across the county for decades to come.The Loch CentreAdditionally, enjoy has reached out beyond its county borders to generate lasting partnerships with stakeholders from across the country Community Leisure UK, sportscotland, NHS, Macmillan Cancer Support and ious national sporting bodies to expand our knowledge, capabilities and opportunities to encourage more local residents to enjoy being physically active.In total, enjoyleisure has welcomed an incredible . million visitors over the last  years. We couldnrsquot have achieved this without the support of our customers, our colleagues and most of all our partners East Lothian Council.The last  months have been the most trying and testing for our organisation, our customers, our colleagues and every inidual across the country.Musselburgh Sports Centre. Picture: Google MapsHowever, itrsquos the support, strength, encouragement and unity within our communities that has enabled us all to prevail.For enjoyleisure, we take inspiration from this experience, harnessing the community spirit that wersquove witnessed and received, so we can strengthen our resolve and ensure that we can make East Lothian the best place in Scotland to live, work and, most of all, enjoyleisure!Herersquos to the next decade and beyond!Bill AxonChief executiveenjoyleisure

title: eyesore-stadium-structure-pulled-houses-built
story: Scottish housebuilder Ambassador Living is set to break ground on fields at Barbachlaw Farm to provide a mixture of three, four and five-bedroom homes, including  affordable homes.The new development, called Wallace Park, will see two executive show homes launched next summer.Initial clearance will now start on site, including the demolition of the nearby steel structure of the greyhound stadiumrsquos proposed main stand, which has stood as an lsquoeyesorersquo for  years, at Victory Lane.The greyhound stadium project was officially scrapped only recently ndash  years after its plans were first put forward.The Courier previously reported that the firm behind the greyhound stadium, Sirius Sport and Leisure, successfully applied to build housing on adjoining land at Barbachlaw Farm over the years, arguing that it was the only way to fund the project.However, the housing was tied into an agreement with East Lothian Council that the racing venue would be built.The council has agreed to release the firm from the obligation after it applied for a change to conditions to allow family butcher John Gilmour to take over the land.It was revealed that John Gilmour Butchers had come to a conditional agreement with Sirius Sport and Leisure to take on the stadium site.In a statement lodged with the council in support of the application, the family butcherrsquos firm said it intended to move its Macmerry operations to the site so that it could expand.The firm wants to create a new butchery, a processing facility for a new range of plant-based foods, a deli, food hall and create  new jobs.Ambassador Living has also acquired land, separate from the stadium site, for the new housing.Gordon Coster, the companyrsquos managing director, said: ldquoWe are delighted to have successfully acquired the land for our new development in East Lothian.ldquoThis exciting acquisition will now allow us to move forward with creating a stunning new aspirational neighbourhood focusing on spacious modern living.ldquoWe are looking forward to bringing the premium offering from Ambassador Living to East Lothian and introducing buyers to the high-quality specication and finishes on offer within our homes.ldquoWe have enjoyed a great deal of early interest in this development, which lies in the heart of an important growth area.ldquoWith its proximity to Edinburgh and well-established amenities and good schooling options, we expect this only to increase as we move towards our sales launch and invite homebuyers to register their interest early.A story: Concerns about the state of Brown Street have regularly been passed on to East Lothian Council.Now, a survey has been created to share the strength of feeling about the issue.Stuart Pe-Win, chairman of Haddington Central Tenants and Residents Association , felt the area, sandwiched between High Street and neighbouring Market Street, was not helping the townrsquos historic image.He said: ldquoThe big problem,you drive into the town, you go right past the place, you literally stop at the lights and look to your right and most often there are big bags of rubbish, green bins and people chucking stuff, and just a decaying building.Last year, Councillor Shamin Akhtar, who represents Haddington on East Lothian Council, was joined by representatives of Haddingtonrsquos community council and Haddington Business Community Partnershipto see the issues for themselves.East Lothian Council previously created a five-year strategy to ldquoincrease the vibrancy and vitality of the town centre.However, Mr Pe-Win, who lives on nearby Cross Lane, felt progress was not fast enough and noted some residents had moved from their home, having grown frustrated with the state of the area.He noted that fly-tipping and anti-social behaviour were still problems.He said: ldquoIrsquove known a couple of people who have moved away because of the anti-social behaviour.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed plans were being drawn up to look at sites on Brown Street.She said: ldquoThe councilrsquos housing department is currently exploring a further two development opportunities at Brown Street.ldquoWork is currently under way to explore options to improve this area and the community will be consulted on proposals prior to any application being submitted.Copies of the questionnaire can be found in Haddingtonrsquos John Gray Centre or by going to surveymonkey r CLXH

title: public-urged-plant-tree-jubilee
story: Next year marks  years since the Queen took to the throne, with a nationwide initiative already drawn up to mark the occasion.The Queenrsquos Green Canopyis calling on people from throughout the country to lsquoplant a tree for the jubileersquo.East Lothianrsquos Lord Lieutenant, Roderick Urquhart, has planted the first tree in the countyrsquos contribution to the cause at Leuchie House, near North Berwick.The independent charity supports people with a range of neurological conditions and their families, and is celebrating its th anniversary.Joining Mr Urquhart at the planting were the countyrsquos Provost John McMillan Sir Hew Dalrymple, Deputy Lord Lieutenant and Mark Bevan, chief executive of Leuchie House.The Lord Lieutenant said: ldquoThe QGC provides opportunities for a lasting memorial to Her Majestyrsquos reign in an accessible and truly environmental manner.ldquoTrees will be planted on a iety of sites across the county and will be a lasting and living memorial fittingly reflecting the longevity of the Queenrsquos reign.ldquoI was delighted to help kick this off by planting a tree in Leuchie Housersquos grounds.The scheme is open to everyone, from iniduals to groups and schools, to participate in.Trees should be planted between October and March, with the tree-planting season starting again in October next year through to the end of the jubilee year.Sir Hew Dalrymple, who is co-ordinating the East Lothian participation with support from East Lothian Council, encouraged people to get involved.He said: ldquoThe idea of the QGC is about giving everyone ndash from iniduals to community groups, schools to businesses ndash a means of contributing to a national initiative locally.ldquoAnybody can join in over the next  months ndash plant a tree, take a photo and log it on the Queenrsquos Green Canopy website.More information on the scheme can be found at queens greencanopy.org

title: halloween-guising-scotland-meaning-different-trick-treating
story: But did you know the term is unique to Scotland and Ireland Heres everything you need to know about the Scots term guising, how it dfers from trick or treating and other Scottish Halloween traditions.Guising derives from the word disguise, and is based on the notion that people dress up at Halloween.Children dress up and go from house to house, telling jokes and stories or singing songs in exchange for sweeties and food.The Collins dictionary defines guising as "the practice orcustomofdisguisingoneself infancydress, often with amask, andvisitingpeoples houses, especially atHalloween".According to folklore, children dressed up so they could venture out safely without wicked ghouls detecting them.Homeowners may leave pumpkins or decorations outside their houses to indicate they are welcoming guisers.Yes, guising is dferent to trick or treating.Traditionally, guising requires you to tell a story or a joke or sing a song, while trick or treating simply requires going up to doors and calling "trick or treat".Treat usually refers to a sweetie or food item, while trick refers to thethreat ofa trick being played on homeownersthey dont offer a treat.There are a few moreScottish Halloween traditions aside form guising.Before pumpkin carving became the done thing, Scots traditionally carved turnips instead and filled them with candles.Apple dookin is also a Scottish tradition people have to get apples out of a basin of water using just their mouths.Alternatively, people hold forks in their mouths and drop them from a distance in an attempt to stab an apple.Another tradition was especially for newly engaged couples the couple would each burn a nut on the fire andthe nuts burned quietly a happy union lay ahead, whilethey crackled and hissed there was more likely a turbulent future.A game that has been modernised is treacle scones - back in the day, people used to try to eat scones suspended with strings without using their hands.Nowadays, this game tends to be played using donuts.

title: black-friday-2021-black-friday-year-uk---date-time
story: Originally an American tradition which sees huge discounts the day after Thanksgiving, it has now become a global phenomenon.It tends to mark one of the busiest shopping days of they year, and in , UK retail sales in November grew faster than in December for the first time.Since the concept arrived in the UK in , Black Friday has developed and evolved: last year Amazon offered discounts for the entire month ofDecember, rather than a specic day.And after Black Friday the sales keep rolling in, withCyber Monday and then the Christmas sales.Heres what you need to know about this years Black Friday sales...Black Friday will take place this year on Friday November .Black Friday officially begins at am, however the exact time sales start is at the discretion of independent retailers.The sales usually last the whole weekend until the end of Cyber Monday.However, based on previous years many shops will begin their sales weeks before, and continuefor around a weekahead of the Christmas period.Cyber Monday is an initiative launched by retailers to encourage people to shop online and is viewed as an online equivalent to Black Friday.It has previously been named the busiest online shopping day of the year in the UK and this year,Cyber Monday will take place on November .Black Friday is your chance to grab a bargain on everything from clothes to technology.While it is up to independent retailers whether or not they put on a sale, many use it as an opportunity to boost sales ahead of the Christmas rush.It is a good chance to get to grips with your Christmas shopping, but you will need to be quick as deals can cause websites to crash and items to sell out quickly.
